I was expecting this to maybe kinda pass muster, but they rocked this thing for real. So, how to build on Civilization V, which itself is one of the best games ever made?   1. Diplomacy is more natural, but also has more depth.  2. You really can't just declare war on anyone, at any time without consequences.  3. Leaders actually do have different personalities, and it comes through well.  4. Civics and culture are relevant now.  5. The districts system brings an interesting new dimension to strategy.  6. Separate, visible map AND game seeds.  7. Much better handling of wonders, and not only via graphics.  8. The AI doesn't do blatantly, obviously stupid things. GET CIVILIZATION VI!!!  Civilization VI is one of the greatest games I have ever played. Civilization V was my first civ game and I have enjoyed it for over 430 hours and many months. Civilization VI feels like a giant step UP from it's predecessor and I can't stop enjoying myself. There is an endless list of pros for the game, such as the amazing graphics, districts functionality, and modding potential. Only a few cons stand out in Civ VI, which are probably the result of the release. There are always issues in a game that has been rushed to release, like this game feels. For example:  1. The settings are a bit limited. Although you can change more graphics settings with NVIDIA, there are few things in-game that you can adjust to you liking, especially those to do with gameplay.  2. The AI. Many people have been complaining about how terrible the AI is and I can partially agree with them. The AI is pretty stupid, but at least it works okay in multiplayer. They listened to us for the modding capabilities, so I am sure they will listen to us on the AI, in the sense that this will be fixed soon.  3. Few minor bugs. There are always a few minor bugs when a new game is put out, but these have yet to be fixed. For example, you can't delete certain religious units (I can't get rid of a missionary of the wrong religion), cities cannot be renamed, and a long loading screen upon resuming your game.  Overall, I think Civilization VI's extreme potential and hype mostly still lives, but if you give it more time, things may get even better. No matter how things are, you will always find yourself playing for hours at a time, enjoying every single minute of it! BUY THIS GAME!!!

I have played this game for 5 hours nonstop now, so here's my two cents. The game is really good in comparison to some of the other civilization installments. Beyond Earth, for example, doesn't even compare to this. The new mechanics are really pleasing. Now when you want to build something, you have to build the specific district which will have a list of building options. This is in contrast to the earlier civilization games where you could just build your buildings. Districts also take up space, so you need to manage the land a little bit more. The biggest difference in this game is for me is the technology. Now there are Eurekas in the game that speed up your research. So what do you have to do to get these Eurekas you ask? Well... You have to complete the specific task prior to or during researching the specific technology. For people like me who try to build science buildings to rush a science victory, it really makes them have to allocate resources differently. I was behind in science in my game even when focusing on science only because I didn't do the Eureka boosts. Overall very good game and with a few dlcs and mods, it will be a masterpiece.

Cons - UI needs improvement. e.g. Trade routes doesn’t show the previous destination after complete it, making difficult to manage on more than 5 cities. / Diplomatic information based on too many notifications - Rework espionage system is critical.
Best Civ game in the series.

This game is a classic example of a sequal that got a lot right, but also took a lot of steps backwards. I have played every civ game extensively since Civ 3, I also played the original Sid Meiers Colonization back in the day, and I can say this game needs more work, akin to how Civ5 was not very good until the expansions fixed it. I cannot recommend until they fix it, and to be honest I have a good feeling they leave out features on purpose so they can sell us expansion packs, they literally made some of the same mistakes they had with Civ 5 and then fixed, but then made them again in 6...   1) The UI is pretty dreadful, some information is needlessly hidden behind + buttons, the mini map looks really bad, some of the past information is no longer availible, for example you cannot see an overview of countries excess resources and relations, at least not that I have found.. even scrolling the map with the mouse at the edge of the screen doesn't work well... but the worst has to be the notifications on the right, which only pop up half the time i put my mouse over them. Or how about the 2 second lag time it takes to bring up specifics about a tile you hovering over?? Hot keys are also bad.   2)Graphics are usually a non issue for me, especially in a strat game, but I must say.. it is like it took a step BACKWARDS. It literally looks worse then Civ5, it is much harder to destinguish roads, hills, and other features on the map, and the AI leaders look SO cartoonish that its just silly.. like characatures of leaders, political cartoons... not a fan. The fog of war seems so clunky also.. I don't know how to say it but I have a hard time telling fog of war from unexplored from terrian sometimes.   3)What the hell happened to the sentry feature?!? Am I missing it?? Now you can fortify some units.. but not all... and put all to 'sleep' but you can no longer foritfy until an enemy comes into range?? That feature was nearly crucial for anti-barbarian and anti-submarine picket lines... now I have to like go manually looking around my borders to make sure no enemy units are simply walking past my 'sleeping' defenses... really bad form.   4) Strat. Resources should be put back to the Civ 5 method... needing only 1 or 2 of a resource to build endless legions of a unit is really a step backwards... it also means countries really don't have incentive or nessecity to start wars for resources... when previously it was much more realisitc, if you had only 3 oil and your opponent had 10... he was going to be producing a LOT more tanks and air craft... so you better come up with a solution by either trading for more, or attacking someone to steal theirs before it was too late... As it stands in Civ 6, a small empire with 1 uranium or oil can produce as many resource specific units as a large empire that has many many resources. I just don't understand this move, was it meant to make it easier for smaller countries, in a game that has basically nerfed the tall build by adding districts?? I am confused. Also, some resources like Iron don't seem to be needed at all... you can skip right over it without blinking.   5) Movement needs some serious work... it can literally take 9 or 10 turns to march your own army through your own land between only 2 cities of yours. I mean.. at least try to make it synch up with the year counter... it takes hundreds of years for an army to march from one city to the neighboring city?? Moving through terrian is way too difficult now that they have removed the 'holdover' point.. aka in Civ 5 if you had a single movement point remaining, you could use it to cross into a space that normally took 2 points, like crossing a river or going up a hill. In Civ6, you NEED 2 points no matter what.. so if you are moving from grassland to grassland then to woods... you move 1 tile to grassland, sit there till next turn.. then 1 tile into woods.. and sit there till next turn.. and then another turn to move out of the woods, god FORBID there is a hill or river or more woods, that means it took you 4 turns to move 4 tiles... 4 tiles which is basically the limits of a single cities border, took an entire 4 turns.. that is absurd. Increase base movement points for all units to 3 points, and go from there, that would help the early game movement a LOT. Keep in mind, you cannot manually build roads till mid-game when you get military engineer, and even then its a pain in the ♥♥♥ because they are relatively expensive to build, and can only build 2 tiles of roads before they are gone. Oh, and they follow the same movement restrictions as any normal unit so it takes 25 turns to get them to where you need them to build a road in the first place. Really tedious and absurd, I don't want to spend half my night simply marching a few units 1/10 of the way across the map.   6)What is the deal with the AI?? It is almost nonsensical. I know they tried this agenda and hidden agenda thing.. and it KIND OF works, but also is very broken. There are just too many variables or something, everyone ends up all mixed up in terms of relations. I don't even understand the delegate and embassy thing to be honest, its just kind of annoying... there doesn't seem to be ryhme or reason behind when they accept or don't accept. The AI also seems to spam really weak units and then never upgrade. I have had multiple games where its me with tanks and helos vs 1000 horseman... and city states seem to do the same thing.   7) Why is the tech tree wrecked so badly? You can skip right through to artillery and infantry before you have basically any other techs researched. You can skip entire generations of units it seem..? Also why did they remove whole eras of units, things move way to quick now you go from musketmen to infantry BAM, no real rifleman, no great war infantry, just bam. Same thing with aircraft, they are back to just defaulting to world war 2 era... they fixed this in civ 5 in the expansions, so why regress now?? No great war tanks! BOO   I don't mean to just bash the game, it has a lot of nice addtions, just needs some work. I like many things about this game and the direction it moved it. But please there are some mistakes here that make it seem like the people that made it have no experience even playing Civ...

Another thing that doesn't work smooth it is the  moving cursor to the sides screen to scroll  the map indeed get blocked by the UI in some points, as is as I would add the possibility to let to scroll the orizontal menus (like the researches) by just grabbing any point over it (like in the map over the land) cause it came more natural then use just the apposite scroll button, and is more intuitive.  I still miss, in this and later release, the massive combats, anyway they improved it a bit comparing to the V chapter.  I can't find yet a panel to look and to easly locate units around the map. A fine start to what will undoubtedly be a more polished game by the end of its lifespan.  I know many people have experienced bugs, I know many people have experienced balancing flaws that turn games into 'gimmes.' While I know of these, I haven't encountered any myself nor have I been trying to and so I will only speak to my own experiences.  The willingness to revamp several of the 'outer-core' mechanics is what sells me on this game. Cities are no longer striving towards the same homogenous endpoint. Warfare no longer consists of solely having the best cross-section of quantity and technological advancement. Diplomacy with AI or Human players is expanded. City-States provide worthwhile returns on investments without taking center stage. Natural Wonders provide cumulative bonuses to several tiles rather than a large, one-off bonus. And so on.  My biggest criticisms on this game compared to V would be the artistic changes. The art style is, to my way of thinking, a step back from V's, particularly the models for Leaders. In turn, while V's more realistic, animated intro scenes ran smoothly, even the lowest setting for the animated Leader scenes in VI run poorly. The New Game intro-narrations in V were read like funeral orations, exalting the Leader for all the great achievements they had in life and were tailored to each leader's cultural idioms; in VI the narration is brief, the first paragraph is generic, the leader-specific paragraph is boring and nebulous, the narrator makes no attempt to correctly pronounce names and all of this compounded by the loading screen taking much longer than the already long load times of V.  Still, this is a fine entry in a fine series. If you enjoy strategy games and are more of a Risk player than a Chess player, I wholeheartedly recommend this game.

I haven't played too much yet but my initial opinions are positive and this is the best base civ game to launch so far but it is definitely worse than Civ V with all expansions (without expansions civ V was horrible). But when some balancing is done with expansions this game will most likely be way better than 5.    Pros: - Game isn't lacking too many major features unlike older base games - Has a great soundtrack, composed by Christopher Tin who composed Baba Yetu - Has a lot of new mechanics that are good like district system, religious combat, casus beli for declaring war, better espionage system ... etc. - Other than minor UI bugs that will probably get fixed soon, doesn't have bugs, and runs fine without crashing (unlike civ V) - Diplomacy is mostly better, denounciations and friendships mean something now and you can now ignore the war requests (When you have military units near their border they ask if you will declare war) as well. - Civics (Culture researches) and technology tree are now seperate giving you a better way advance your civ in the way you want. - City state relations are not based on gold anymore, so it is easier to take advantage of them now, and they are more useful than before - Trade routes make the roads so you don't need to worry about connecting cities anymore, which would be a nightmare since workers have limited uses now. Also cargo ships and caravans are replaced by a trader, so you don't need 2 types of trade units. - Better strategy view and useful lenses.  Cons: - Game is not balanced good enough. - In early game you are always under attack since all AI does is spam military units. - Late game is also bad because it is boring. After some point mid-game it is obvious who is going to win and who will lose and there is very little you can do to change that (It was obvious in Civ V too but you could fix that if you are losing, or someone could make a comeback and become batter than you). - Civilopedia is lacking some information. - Having a bad starting location basically kills your chance at winning since it is a lot more important now because of the district adjacency and housing systems. - Doesn't have the world congress. - Some wonders are objectively a lot less beneficial than other wonders (they were closer in civ V), and take way too much production even in a highly developed city. - Because of balancing problems you are either doing really well or horribly bad and changing it takes a lot longer than before. - This is more of a personal opinion than a review but not a fan of new cartoony graphics. - In civ V science victory was way too easy and now it is really hard. It needs to be somewhere in the middle.    This game has a lot of potential as the expansions balance the game more and add new features. In its current state it is still good enough for me to recommend it but don't expect a perfect game since it really needs to be balanced better.

Don't get confused by the hours played, I played in offline mode all day yesterday. I have logged over 1000 hours on civ5 and many more on civ1-4. Early this morning I finished a standard game, with a fractal map, all civs, random everything. SO here's my first impressions on the game. I want to start with cons so people don't read half the review and see everything that has already been said about how good it is.  Cons: -Map movement is garbage. Civ5 mouse drag was so smooth, it was like a hot knife cutting through butter. Mouse drag in civ6 is awful. It's so clunky and feels like moving a square rock that keeps falling on its side.  -Difficulty levels are too easy. I played on King last night and the game wasn't even close. The AI isn't smarter, it just gets bonuses like every other civ game.  -AI is terrible at upgrading units. There will be warriors everywhere until the AI gets infantry. This is probably due to a combination of trying to minimize unit costs, and lack of available resources in their lands.  Nitpicky comments: -Why are the menus not sorted? If I want to see victory conditions, or trade route info, this should be sorted from high to low, or at least have a button to sort it. Beyond Earth had this same problem and I don't understand why it's so hard to implement (it's not).  -The fog of war takes too long to go away. I don't really like how it fades after you move to the tile. I wish it would fade away as you were moving.  -There are several graphical glitches that I experienced relating to city walls where the city walls would extend, in a pixilated manner, 3 tiles from the city center. After restarting the game this went away though.  -The civilopedia (is that how you spell it?) is pretty bad in my opinion. It used to be detailed but it just seems very bare bones now.  -No world congress, as far as I could tell, but it was getting pretty late. I thought this was a very nice addition to civ5 and I would love to see it return in a future expansion here.  -I wish that, with the new movement costs, that if you unit can't go anywhere else its turn would just end. Instead, it just sits there like an idiot on a hill with 1 movement left and hills all around it.   -This will never happen and I say it every time a new civ game comes out: please make early game naval units have the ability to go in the ocean, but with some probability that they will be destroyed at the end of turn. I loved this in civ3 and it's been gone since 4.  -Tech tree feels limited. I get that the civics tree should make up for this but it doesn't feel that way. The jump between eras seems very forced rather than flowing like it did in civ5.  -Game froze upon exit twice.  -Can you not negotiate with another civ about making peace with someone?  Pros: -Game is beautiful. I personally love the art style. Yes, some units look cartoony, but overall the look is very crisp.  -Love that everything has a build animation. Especially wonders, as you can see them being constructed, and then, bringing back some civ4 vibe here, see a small movie of the entire construction.  -Unit 'stacking' is back, but not in the way of stack of doom. This time you can group a certain number of units together to form corps, and eventually armies. The addition of support classes is a very nice addition as well.  -I very much enjoy the unstacking of cities. Districts make the game feel much more personal, and adds an entire additional layer of depth into the game. Most buildings within each district also feel like they belong there, rather than just placing random things in each one so that the tile gets filled up.  -AI does seems better at managing combat, not by much, but definitely better than vanilla civ5. But, see previous comment, AI is horrendous at upgrading units.   -Maps are amazing, and distribution of resources doesn't feel forced or completely random.  -Music is the best of any civ game. Yes, 4 has Baba Yetu, but the main theme of 6 is pretty close, and the in-game music is just incredible.   -Supposedly, 6 has even better mod support than 5, and 5 has over 5,000 mods.  -New engine feels great, as buildings are built on the environments you build them on, rather than being the same thing placed wherever. Also, mulithreading support is a nice addition, and turn time s absolutely improved.   -Leader screens are nice, and the amount of information in each diplomacy screen is waaaaaaay more than civ5.  -No more global happiness, which was a bad addition, but health still isn't back in from 4. Instead you have manage amenities. I mean, it's the same mechanic, with a different name, but it seems much more forgiving than the happiness mechanic.   -Nukes are great. Enough said.     I could go on for days. Essentially this game is easily the best civ game at launch, there's no debating this. Are there some bugs, yea. Does it needs balancing badly, yes. But it hasn't even been out for 48 hours, so be patient. The team behind this game seems very devoted to keeping up with the game, unlike some games, so I have no doubt that this game will receive just as much attention as 5 did. 6 also has so much on release day that 5 didn't have until its third expansion, and over $120 later. So I can't wait to see what the expansion(s) for 6 will bring (I know Ed Beach mentioned at least 1 expansion being planned).  Overall, this is really good game. On-par with brave new world in my opinion (assuming balance patches come out), and is absolutely worth the $60 price tag. If you love civ, buy this, you wont be disappointed.  Final Score: 92/100

Is Civ6 a perfect game? No.  Is it a fun game? Yes  I have played every iteration of Civilization and with every change over there are complaints and issues. These are all fair enough, as things we have loved are changing. But, over time, they will sort themselves out as get used to them.   Of all the vanilla releases of Civ this is, by far, the deepest. There are new mechanics and concepts that really take the series in a good direction, such as districts and AI agendas. However, they really need to polish the game a bit more, as some of these great ideas have issues (eg it can be very hard to keep anyone liking you, and there may be no way to prevent it. The warmonger penalty may be excessive. etc).  But there is one GLARING negative. The AI. Civ4 and 5 both suffered with horrendous AI upon release, and 6 continues this trend. The AI is PATHETIC. They often refuse to attack, instead shuffling their units about infront of your army while being massacred by ranged attacks. They don't seem to use districts overly well... it's not thought out to flow across the empire. Instead being a random mix that doesn't necessarily help them. And it's plain too easy to win, even on the hardest difficulties.  Complaints about the art style will likely fade. People hated Civ4's art initially, but now love it. It is just jarring when you look at something you are not used to. Yes, it could use some touch ups as it can be hard to distinguish hills, but overall it looks amazing.   Will this get better? Yes. Civ 4 and 5 had similar issues and they were ironed out. Civ6 is still very playable and very fun. It's not up to the standards of Civ4 BTS, or Civ5 BNW, but let's not forget they had 2 expansions and then almost a year of patches to become the masterpieces they ended up being.

Does it have its flaws? Yes. But Civilization VI is a good and valid continuation of the Civilization Franchise. The AI is not the greatest--and sometimes it is downright atrocious--but three months after the game's release, the developers at Firaxis have already released two patches tweaking the AI and rebalancing the game. They are very much involved with the community and are seeking to better the product they created.   The gameplay mechanics are fun. Unstacking the cities adds a new twist to the mundane city-building of past Civ games, and the Eureka/Inspiration systems provide neat side-quests to keep the mid-game from getting boring. All-in-all, it is a work-in-progress, as all Civ games are post-release, but it is a lot of fun to play.

Overall this is a strong addition to the franchise. The district mechanic adds a wonderful layer to city planning that on it's own practically makes 6 worth it. I'm also delighted by the addition of map pins, and the introduction of corps/armies is a great compromise between Civ4 and Civ5 military tactics.   That said, there are significant flaws that we really shouldn't have to play through while they hotfix. First and foremost is the AI; this is the least competitive (borderline inept) AI in the series and makes me concerned that the franchise may be heading towards multiplayer focus to the exclusion of single player. AI doesn't yet know how to wage war effectively, settle cities in logical places, pick district locations strategically, etc. It's frustrating because Domination victory in particular feels quite hollow when the enemy won't fight back.   Another major step back in 6 is the reporting/UI features, which have been radically pared down since 5. Anyone who used the different advisor reports, military overview, trade overview, notification log, demographics, etc to help manage their civ will feel they are flying blind in 6. HATE IT.   They also drastically reduced the number of civs and leaders, leaving out some major favorites like Persia, Mongols, and Babylon but I can only assume these will be forthcoming in DLC form or expansions. More concerning is the restrictively small selection of maps- what happened to Terra? Earth? Small Continents? Tilted Axis? Very disappointing.   Still, this game is an improvement over 5. Let's all cross our fingers and hope the most glaring feature oversights get sorted out and the various bugs and glitches (some game breakers in here, really can't believe they shipped like this) get fixed pronto.

I love the majority of the civ series. This one is not the worst, nor is it the best. This one is better than Civ 5, but not as good as Civ 3 or 4. I haven't played 1 or 2 in so long I can't compare since I remember how much I loved the games but I'm not sure if my recollection is accurate enough of those two to compare. Over all the best of the breed remains Civ3 with Civ4 being a close 2nd.  There are several game design flaws in this game. Not just 'Oh I wish they'd done 'this' or 'that'. The game is just full of changes. Most of which are very obviously change for the sake of change rather then change to make it a better game.  Diplomacy does not work at all. It is never rational or reasonable. And it progresses fairly quickly to everyone hates everyone so it is not just broken in the human v. AI. An example, you crush a foe; they are down to their last city and they beg for peace but the only terms they will accept is with you giving them all your cash on hand and all the cash you earn every turn, and give them back a couple of the cities you captured. What you can ask for in diplomacy is broken. I was at war with Sumeria. Russia and India hated Sumeria and had 'denounced them'. But I could not ask them to join in the war, I could only ask them to start a new war against each other. You can't even do basic things like share maps. Declarations of war have nothing to do with their ability to win the war or even their preparedness to wage a war. The chinese declared war with only 4 military units, not a single one of which was close to current tech. Also the AI declaring love or hate based on nonsensical things is just plain stupid. Why in the world would any nation declare affection for another because the other built a factory, a sailboat, or hate one because they built a fancy light house? it is random nonsense in the place of actual logic based diplomacy.   Economics does not work at all. A 6 city empire can make just as much or more cash as a 40 city one. Trade routes are more important than any thing else. In fact most everything else (economically) can be ignored until your trade routes are full and then only build it when you don't have anything more important to build. In a game I recently played a 6 city empire had a larger military and more cash on hand than mine with close to 40 cities.  Road build 'works' but is done in the most annoying way they could devise. Workers can not build roads, only military engineers can, but should have been called 'Combat engineers'. 'Combat engineers' can only be built in cities with a 'barracks' (now called an encampment). They can only build 2 roads (or other items) and then disappears. 'Caravans' (now called Traders) will sometimes build roads (and will other times decide to go over water). So you are stuck using one of your cities to nearly constantly build 'road builders' since these units take about as long to build as most actual military units.  The tech tree is short and completed rather quickly. At which point everyone is equal for however long the game lasts. Boring.  City management is cumbersome. There are no build ques. Unlike previous versions you can't simply drag a city 'worker' to the new task. You must lock all the citizens in place except for the only one you want to move. Well now, that makes perfect sense to no one. click on and Lock 20 rather than just click on the one you want to move.  City state is a cute idea done badly. You surround a city state. A rival can send enough envoys to become their 'Suzerain' and the city state will then follow that empire to war. The equivalent of this occurred. Kansas city decided that Taiwan was their most favorite place in the world. For some reason Taiwan declared war on the USA. So Kansas City followed their lead. They send out half a dozen spearmen to face down the american tanks. Sending envoys leads to that city state granting your civilization their magic power, um ok??  Naval power is a joke. Most of the ships of previous games have been removed. Even cargo ships are non-existent since just moving a unit in to the water turns them in to a transport ship.  Air power is poorly and awkwardly done as well. Even the AI seems to know it since I played to 2096 and never did see an enemy plane.  Military power in general is going to disappoint. If you play to for a domination victory you'll hate this the most of all. The AI uses no logic at all. Units are just randomly sent your direction. A few 'artillery' units, but not escorted. Unit combat strength make no sense. APC's can destroy a max-tech tank. A tank can attack and destroy a helicopter, so even the old rock-paper-scissors part of the old combat logic is broken. Cavemen damage tanks with their sticks. There are game imbalancing things which can not be undone. For example, one AI had a tank 'base' strength of 107. While in my case they had a base strength of 90. I compared policies, government bonuses, religions and so forth. So far as I can tell I had all the stuff which gives you a bonus and he had none. It was not one unit which happened to be high level, but all this units had a 17 point 'head start' within nothing in the game giving it to him. This 17 point head start translates in to needing a 3:1 advantage in number to prevail. Not impossible, but given the way units work in game (limited stack possibilities, 1 unit per tile) it was vexing. The only thing equalizer was the AI's lack of tactics or logic beyond drive our stuff towards the nearest city in an unorganized mob.  The game over all feels half-baked (as in they took it out of the oven before it was done). The nations and leaders bonuses and such are not at all equal. I doubt much attention was payed to game balancing. The load times, turn lengths, responsiveness are all bad. Even on very high end computers. Scrolling the map up to move a unit, for example, is very time consuming as it is hit or miss if the map will scroll at all.  There are more issues, but for me these are the high-lights. Your love/hate of the game will depend on how much control you want (the more you want, the less you'll like this game). If you have played and enjoyed the previous versions (other than 5), this may well impact your ability to enjoy this one. If you like a 'war' game this one will drive you nuts.

- Pro Con list down below -   I've played Civ5 over 600 hours, skipped the dud that was CIV BE and came back to this with dripping wet panties - and it satisfied all the hopes I had for it.  It can be said, without restriction, that Civ6 picks up where Civ5 + DLCs left off, took the good things and made them greater, and took the things that weren't as desirable (AI diplomacy was straight up bullsh*t, pardon my french) and improved them by lengths.   Having read several complaints that the AI is crap in diplomacy, I cannot confirm that. It's less random and more predictable, if anything else.   What Firaxis couldn't improve on, was the crappy Battle AI. Going to war with any AI is simply too easy, and sometimes just annoying, like swatting at flies that sit on your face on a hot day.   Speaking of war, the warmongering mechanic is perhaps the single most annoying thing in Civ6. It doesn't seem to disappear, so you'll be marked a warmonger forever and ever, even if the year is 2025 and you razed a few cities back in the ancient era. If there is a way to reduce warmongering, please feel free to notify me - because I havent figured out how.  Which brings me to another thing: the new big additions, like the city districts are explained well - but all the other little changes? They're just there, leaving you to sink and swim. It took me forever to find the WMDs I had produced, I was utterly confused as to where the citizen management went, and for the love of christ almighty where do I delete buildings I have built ? Nowhere? What? Really? Damn.   Conclusion: While the game came out strong and blew me off my feet, there is undoubtedly a lot of little issues that dull the shiny, glorious achievement that is this game. Having said that, this game is not unplayable! Quite the opposite - it's excellent regarding game play and flow. It simply has occasional hiccups, that should be fixed with coming patches.   Pros: - Better diplomacy (Agendas make the AI more readable) - Very nice graphical overhaul.  - District Tiles are very cool addition. - Espionage is devious - spawn partisans, blow up districts, steal art, tech and gold! - Civics allow a very varied play style   Cons: - Agendas are a bit stale - there are two per NPC and they remain the same throughout the game.  - UI is just a bit too cluttered and unintuitive at times (I'm looking at you, damn x button) - Some bugs force you to reload the last save (sometimes the 'unit requires orders' button wont disappear after you've given the unit an order. It doesnt break the game, but it's annoying. Happened 3 times in 26 hours of game time so far). - The warmongering mechanic is frustrating (Ghandi denounces me for my warmongering 200 years ago - you need to let it go, pal.) - some new mechanics are not well explained (I played 'Find the WMD!' for 10 minutes until I finally realized you need to manually load them to a sub or silo. A President's worst nightmare).

TLDR: Most fresh and exciting game in the civilization series, a worthy addition that will stand the test of time!  As someone who put many huindreds of hours (not a figure of speech) into Civ games, I was really excited when Civ 6 got announced. As many others, I got disappointed by the cartoony art style, but as details on gameplay started to be revealed, I started getting hyped. And sure enough, I fell in love with Civ 5 after my first game. I got used to the art style so fast, and the game is fresh and well-made..well, I guess this is my life now!   This review is meant to discuss all the new additions in Civ 6 over the previous games in the series, especially Civ 5. If you haven't played Civilization before then what on earth are you waiting for? Buy it now!  Things done better than before:  - Districts: This is probably the biggest departure from previous civ games. Forces meticulous planning ahead and city specialization more than ever.  - Civics: Having a civics tree that runs on culture parallel to the science tech tree? Unlocking governments and policies that can totally change the game and give more customization options that ever before? The ability to plan around civics completion time s and inspirations and when a specific bonus is needed at which time? Yes please!  - Boost and Inspirations: Civilizaiton is now less tedious and more dynamic than ever..you will ALWAYS be looking to achieve those conditions that boost your science and civics, trying to plan ahead and use what you got, even switching at times a tech or a civic half way to save it for the boost, and you will have to decide when you really need to rush this tech or civic now and can't relaly wait for the boost.  - Religious victory: That's how I won my first game! It's a new rutheless type of war, building on the religion system from civ 5, but adding a much more hectic and fast paced race..suffice to say your religion can actually get erased from the world if you're not tenacious enough! And religious units can fight each other with bolts of lightning (sound rediculous for civ but it's glorious in action, trust me!)  There are many other new mechanics, but I think I mentioned the most game-changing ones, as well as the ones that really left an impact on my soul!   Things that need to improve:  - Civilopedia: The most negative thing I've encountered so far. I've consulted the civilopedia dozens of times i-game, and not a single time (no exaggeration) did I find the piece of info I was looking for. More than often the keyword I was searching for did not turn any result, and when it did, the info I found were so brief and vague that I didn't find the specific thing I was looking for.  - UI: the UI is not bad by any means but still needs some polish IMO. Things like city production turns not updating on the same turn, no Alert (fortify until enemy in range) function for units, no option to turn off auto-siwtching for units, and limited hotkeys selection..and a lot more tiny quality of life sutff that needs some extra polish.  - Diplomacy: The bane of civ games. I still face the same problems as before. I actually now feel it's much harder now to please other civs than before. I know you're not meant to be able to please them all, but even pleasing one is difficult.. guess having 2 agendas for every leader that can immensly affect their opinions, as well as the factors of government and religions and others, make it very unlikely to have more positive than negative stuff with any civ..I have no idea how this can be improved, but it really does need improving.  That's it for now! I may edit and update this review later as I play more games. Now go stand the test of time!

This civ game is as good as any other. It is a lot of fun and I see a lot of benefits to this one over the others.  The music in the game is great. I'm not sure if it is just me, but there are the main musical pieces that play through the game, and then there are variations of those same pieces depending on some factor. I'm not sure if this is if you are at war or depending on what era you are in, but it changes and it is very cool. The characters and interacting with other civilizations is very nice. When in a character screen, the music changes to that specific civ and you can hear the little claps of Pedro IIs shoes on the ground as he walks around if he is mad at you. You can hear the *clinks* of his necklace. You can hear the fan of Elizabeth as she gets nervous over war. All of this makes the civilization's leader feel alive and much better than what pictures make the new cartoon look out to be. I have seen people complain about wonders and districts and how they take up room now, but I personally like this feature. It focuses more on strategic placement of districts and the impact on situations from this placement. The cities look really good with a lot of districts and wonders. You feel more personal about your city because of this. Every time a wonder is built by you it does a cinematic view of the wonder and it feels accomplishing. There are a whole lot of new mechanics that make the game a lot better excluding the little things that I discussed above. There is constant visual feedback on your relationship with other civs which is huge as it influences your decisions more than I would think it would. The strategic view is better and could be nice for others. Personally, in Civ V, I thought the strategic view was useless and annoying but in civ 6 it is much better. I have seen complaints about the UI and I did not like it at first but got used to it and actually enjoy it now. The only thing that I would like to see is a border growth timer, as I do not think there is one as of now without doing math. I can see how people would be confused and annoyed by the UI at first. I like the difference in happiness mechanics.  There are a lot of other things I could talk about that make me really enjoy this game. If you really like the civ franchise and you are, of course, willing to see change, then this game is a great buy.  THE MAIN ISSUE I SEE IN OTHER REVIEWS:  The AI seems to be the reason that everyone is not liking this game. That means that if you are not interested in AI and have enough people for an enjoyable game through multiplayer, the game is amazing. As for me, the AI are angry as people have been saying but that is because I am partly playing domination and that is my goal. There are civilizations in my game that I am not being aggressive towards so diplomatically I am happy with them and they are happy with me. I do not see the AI as too easy or not a threat. They have specific criteria that is learned. Sometimes you make promises to them, such as moving troops off of their borders. This could have been unintentional, so you could move them and they will later thank you for keeping the promise.  A lot of people have been complaining about districts and their space. Here are some points that i have seen:  -Cannot remove districts Removing districts? So pick up a huge chunk of your city and just move it somewhere else. This doesn't make sense and it promotes mistakes and lack of city planning. -Takes up a tile I see this as a neat benefit that adds a different strategic aspect of the game, like the Military district acts as a sort of fort to protect units and as another range city attack with walls. The game takes a little time to understand a lot of the concepts and some people will not like that.  I do agree that the AI need to be worked on. If it is a huge deal, don't get the game, but you can still have a lot of fun with flaws in the game. I am having lots of fun and I see myself doing so for a very long time.

I really wanted to like this game. And I'm not one of those types that say 'They changed it now I hate it' because that's not the problem. Actually, I like most of the changes from Civ5 to the new Civ6 game.   The Good  Religion really seems to be a major benefit rather than an add on. Causius Belli (Reason for War) really makes the warmonger penalty make sense. Separation of Civics and Tech works very well. Eureka moments really help make Tech and Civics that work for you. Builder units make sense, and the Trade units build sensible roads. Religious combat (yes, that's a thing) is hilarious. Global happiness is long gone. Please stay dead forever. World Leader animations are charming.  The Bad  The AI. It's just as awful as it was in Civ5, no matter what you read. The unit diversity has been severly simplified, to the point that battles simply become rock-paper-scissors. The neverending barbarians - see below. Critical info is usually buried in some out-of-the-way location, particularly with cities.  The Unplayably Ugly  The new districts feature is an *almost* well-thought out idea. I like the notion of a city 'unstacking' and needing to place little districts around to replresent certain specialisations. The problem comes in the implementation. In the mid-game, all my cities were simply building districts. Not trying new units, not exploring the map, not beating up weaker civs, all I could do was build new districts (because they cost a mountain of production) and move on to the next. The problem was I was doing 'well' and had a number of Great People who produce Great Works, and like in Civ5, Great Works need specific buildings to house them. Unlike Civ5, these buildings required a district to build them, and then the new district required a higher city population to build them, which required a different district to add housing, which cause Amenities (local happiness) to run low, which required a different district to improve, which with so much building to do required an Industrial District.... you get the idea. As written, they're just too labour intensive to use properly.  Speaking of labour intensive.... the automated citizen management for the cities is absolutely terrible. You have to micromanage your citizens from the dawn of time or your citizens will ignore massive gains to work barren tundrid tiles. On top of that, the city info displays are absolutely lackluster. In Civ5 they were piled with too much info, now they're so nuanced it's easy to overlook important details.  The AI. Why oh why? Still will walk a settler right beside your capitol city and found a new one, and act shocked when you declare war, which makes you an unforgivable warmonger for the next 6000 years and all the other AI opponents hate you forever and ever. Especially if you raze it because it was built in an awkward terrible place. Still randomly asks for free stuff for dubious benefit. Still goes cliquey for whatever reason.  As far as the barbarians go... it's strange. In this iteration of Civ, cities are more prominent, but also fewer in number. Especially given the production costs of districts, it's very unlikely you'll go spraying settlers around the map making cities everywhere. This means large segments of the map are and will forever be unwatched, causing barbarians to plague you till the end of time. They're quite dangerous in the early game, but quickly become a nuisance.  Conclusion  Civ6 is an intellectually interesting game, but I can't really call it a fun game, as it gets so mired in district building that there's little else to do (except ignore them entirely and just go kill everyone). I think a few tweaks on balance can probably sort that out, but that still leaves the laughably inept AI and very short unit list, which would are pretty big problems too. I have no doubts that with some polish and some hefty patches they can make this a proper Civ game, but whether 2k will remains to be seen.  'Do You Recommend This Game?'  ... ... ... ...no. I think as the sixth game in the series, it's right to be disappointed that the new systems don't work very well, and the changes that do work were to fix what didn't work in Civ5. I think if you have *never* played any Civ game before, Civ6 is probably the best place to start, but this is the sixth game in the series - getting brand new players in who haven't played the franchise before will be rare.   I really wanted to like this game, but I'll be playing it again when the next major revision comes out.

While I know you can turn it off, there was one game where I did not pursue it and left it on in which pretty much medieval era forward I was swarmed with religious units left and right, taking up a large chunk of my territory. I will say that most vanilla versions of these games are typically horrible, so I can't say I'm not surprised, but this one will need a ton of fixing up before I consider buying the next expansion.

I'll start by saying I believe this game could be, and probably will be, one of the best Civ games of all times. But at this point I can't recommend it. There are plenty of other reviews detailing the horrible state in which this game was released ... moronic AI, numerous UI bugs, lack of information given to the player, and the game is in serious need for a balance overhaul. Although the game is playable, it just isn't fun with all these flaws.   The lack of any information from the devs is dissapointing as well. I know from past Civ games that there tends to be large patches after a month or two instead of multiple small patches, but it would at least be nice to have the developers acknowledge the issues and give us an idea on what they are working on first. Frankly, this game has so many issues I feel they should focus on some smaller, quicker patches first rather than a larger patch that may well break other elements of the game.  I'll change my review when they fix it. Until then I've shelved the game.  Update: After two patches I still cannot recommend this game, and I'm really starting to lose faith in Firaxis. It took them two patches to add something as basic as a unit alert button. When a city production is finished the item it lists as 'last finished' is actually the item before the item was last finished. The game will still freeze sometimes when exiting. The AI is still horrible. There is still a horrible lack of information (without mods); for example you are not informed when a trade deal with another civ ends, or what trade deals you have active with another civ. The trade menu cannot be sorted in any way. The list just goes on and on. There is so much potential in this game, but it still needs a LOT of work.  At this rate, I'd recommend waiting for at least another two patches, which at the current rate will be about 6 months from now.

This game was so disappointing. It's like one step forward and ten steps back. The AI is still awful as expected. Building construction queue was removed for no reason. Units can't move if their movement point is less than the movement cost of the terrain, which results in a tedious slog of chasing a barbarian scout across the map. And what's more tedious is how district production costs go up really quickly based on the number of cities and districts you have, resulting in yet again another midgame tedium of pressing next turn constantly.   However, this time, the early game has some fun tedium too with barbarian outposts spawning constantly in a fog of war. So you better spend some of your early game building scouts to get vision everywhere around your city or an outpost will literally spawn near your city and start spamming at least 6 Spearmen and Horsemen at you in 10 turns.  To compound to this tedium are housing and amenities. Housing is just a specific resource that you get that increases the upper limit of the city's population. Go higher than the amount of housing and your population growth will slow down. Amenities is just happiness, except that instead of empire-wide happiness, it's local happiness instead. And each unique luxury will give 1 amenity to 4 cities. You need 1 amenity per 2 population. And you will run out of amenities quickly, and if you dare reach -2 amenities, your city will start ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ about rebel military units of the highest tech available. And guess what, THERE'S NO WAY TO LIMIT POPULATION GROWTH. THEY REMOVED IT FOR NO REASON.  The worst offender is the UI. Tiny texts, large empty spaces, scroll bars, no unique icons for policies or great people, tiny icons for wonders and buildings. The city amenities menu is just filled up with the word 'amenities' repeated. The city reports menu HAS NO SORTING FOR SPECIFIC YIELDS OR UPKEEP OR AMENITIES. Why would they remove that? Especially since cities need to specialize,   Oh, and as a cherry on top, AI civs will constantly flip out at you because of their agendas. Cleopatra hates weak military and it's turn 10 and you aren't building warriors constantly? DENOUNCED. Germany hates city states and you send an envoy to one? DENOUNCED. I'm an old school wargamer, thank in part to the original Civlization that I played on my Amiga back in the '90s.   So I've watched the entire series progress. 2 was better than 1, 3 was better than 2, 4 was better than 3.... then the progress went in entirely the wrong direction. 5 had some interesting features, I loved the hexagonal map. The game is much prettier than the ones before. But it lost something. It wasn't a wargame any longer, it was... well it was something else.  And whatever that else is, Civlization VI is even more of that. That's not to say there aren't some things I love about Civ VI. The technology tree, the civics system, the governments panel, the way great people are now born, those things are genius. And seriously add some depth to the game in ways it didn't have before.   But it's clearly been dumbed down to be a console game. Where is the sentry command?  Here is something I found personally outrageous. When you put scouts on automatic explore, they stop each time they see a hostile unit and look for your input. But when I put my warrior on fortify, a barbarian slinger came into my city and beat the unholy crap out of him while he just sat there enjoying the free rocks to the head. ??? WTF? Why is it that one type of unit can recognize danger (it actually says danger on the move screen when you're summoned to deal with your terrified scout) but all others just sit there like idiots? I had the game set to auto end turns, so if my city hadn't produced something that needed my attention the warrior would have died of his free rocks to the head overdose.   That's just stupid. This problem could be solved with one command that EVERY other version of Civ had, but this one lacks. Sentry. WT unholy F, Sid Meier. I'm seriously disappointed in your for this one unbelievably stupid change alone.  Is this a great game? Absolutely, and if you're looking for a dumbed down pseudo-wargame, you should buy it. And you will have war, because the moronic AI of the other nations attacks you every time you turn around pretty much regardless of you standings, your previous relationship with them, or anything else for that matter. Then they'll zerg you with whatever unit they like the most, even from across the entire HUGE map. Scythia sent about a dozen horsemen after me, and they literally took 50 turns to get to me from the time the war was declared. I, being unprepared, went down in flames. Spearmen don't seem to have any increased effect against horses at all, as they have in previous iterations.   If you want to play the game I mentioned above, then yeah, I do recommend this game. the videos at the top of the store page for this game tell you exactly what the game play is like, other than the lack of features like SENTRY (durrrrr), rally points, etc.   If you want to play the best Civilization has ever been, do this: Buy Civ IV and all the expansions (it's cheap) and then go to  www.civfanatics.com  and get the mod for the game called Caveman to Cosmos. That mod makes Civ into something beyond anything Sid Meier could ever dream of. Another good one is Fall from Heaven.   So I don't recommend spending $60, or the $80 I spent for this game. Wait until it's $20. It's worth $20.   Now that I have it, I'll probably still play it some, but mostly I'll wait for the modders on here to make this game not suck in the way that PC games shouldn't suck. Add in a sentry command. Add in rally points. More diverse units. Twink the AI so it doesn't act like Hannibal Lecter no matter which leader it is.   For Pete's sake, Sid, I thought you were better than this. Shame on you.

Like many people, my first PC game love was Civ2. I really wanted to love the new instalment. I was always going to buy it. But now I feel I have to warn others not to ...  Civ 6 is just a Disney version of what a Civ game should be.  - It's buggy at release - It is missing lots of quality of life improvements - no govenors, few tool tips, difficult even as an experienced player to know what stuff is, no building queue and constant need to re-direct traders - seriously, that was one of the major irritants of Beyond Earth, so why make us CONSTANTLY re-direct traders? - Can't build roads consciously anymore ... because? There is no strategy. By the end of the turn you can look around a bit if you want but don't try to actually do things in the order you want or you'll accidentally give a stupid move or build order - Religion is just an irritation - Combat is dictated by the PC as it tells you which unit to order and when. Also get used to not knowing why your artillery can't fire  I won my first playthrough. It's not tricky. What they've done is take away tool tips and insert as many irritating mechanics as possible.  And that leaves BARBARIANS. This is basically Civ 6:Barbarians. They are a constant irritation (and I mean constant). Thought your super Empire could focus on external threats? Think again. If you leave JUST ONE hex uncovered the Barbarians will spawn there, every few turns, forever. If you have a City State inside your borders then EVEN IF you can see ever hex, Barbarians will spawn there, forever. Not difficult, but irritating and likely to mess up your trade caravans.  This is just a bad game. It's lazy. No thought went in to it. Hiring Sean Bean shows how this game is produced now. It will have been a group of faceless 'professionals' in some trendy office having a brain leak session about 'how kids love Game of Thrones'. No one actually thought about the game.  This iteration is garbage. Play Civ 5 as that's all this is. Or Play Civ 4 for a good game. Wait until this one is heavily discounted - it will be soon.

CIV VI includes a lot more features compared to Civ V base game (e.g. espionage and faith only included in Civ V expansions) and overall does seem more fun than Civ V vanilla. The mid to end game is not as boring compared to Civ V, but there's still some slowdown. Civ VI makes you plan and think more strategically instead of just following one strategy in every game (e.g. you don't build the same buildings and units in all your cities and you don't follow the same tech tree path route every single game) making replayability a lot more fun.  I think the changes made in Civ VI are in a good direction, all the changes are intended to make you think and plan more strategically and they really fleshed out some of the previously weaker parts of the game (e.g. the faith overhaul in Civ VI is amazing, and science victory now have milestones instead of just stacking great scientists), and hopefully there will be more polish as the game gets patched/new expansions. Also, in Civ V you're nearly always going to play tall if you want to play optimally and roll with only ~4 cities, but in Civ VI because of global happiness being removed you can pretty much play wide and build as many cities as you want, it's a lot more fun to have the choice to play wide and have more cities to manage, than just looking over 4 cities all game.  So overall I would definitely recommend to buy this over Civ V (the music and graphical update themselves are worth it - game looks and sound gorgeous).   I do have some gripes about the game, I guess the launch was a little rushed as most of the problems could easily be fixed if they polished the game more and did some more QA, from their past records they seem to do a good job at patching and polishing games after launch, I don't think any Civ base game launch has been polished enough at launch but they end up able to address most issues after multiple expansions. However, in retrospective, this launch is a lot better compared to Civ V vanilla launch as that game was pretty terrible without all the expansions that were released after launch.  -UI needs major update, missing crucial information and very cluttered.  -Fog of war graphical update is very messy visually, hard to differentiate things.  -Some broken strats like selling units for gold using certain civs  -AI acts a little weird sometimes, like the civ being in modern era but still having tons of warrior units  - they removed a LOT of keyboard shortcuts that were in the game for no seemingly apparent reason. RIP keyboard shortcuts that have been in the game since Civ II... No 'H' to set units to fortify until heal, all builder improvements keyboard shortcut removed like 'I' for farms... the list goes on.  - removed some quality of life improvements in Civ V like cannot set unit to alert mode (fortify and wake up upon seeing an enemy).. having to micromanage every unit by hand is very annoying, unit cycling itself seems a little wonky compared to Civ V as well.  - The horse barbarian camp is so much more op than all the other barbarian camps, seems a little strange.

TL:DR: Wait for mods. Wait for patches. Wait for more honest reviews.   I've put hundreds of hours into Civilization 5. It's probably my favorite game of all time. Needless to say I was pretty amped about Civilization 6 but after getting through a few games I just don't think it's ready for prime time.   - The UI is atrocious. It's probably the worst I've ever seen in a game and that's saying something. Forget getting through the mid to late game in any reasonable length of time because of the 'gossip' pop-ups taking up the entire screen through every turn. I really do not care that Frederick cleared out a barbarian camp on the other side of the map with a musketman. It means absolutely nothing to me.   - The agendas mechanism is laughably broken. For example: Found a religion with Kongo in your game and you will be called out or denounced for not spreading it to him within 1-2 turns. He then continues to taunt you until you do. Because the AI is creating more faith than what's possible they will apostle rush him and convert him to another religion at which point Kongo starts yelling at you again.   Another example: Rome likes countries that have a lot of cities and land. They're your neighbor so you build more because the game doesn't really punish wide empires as much as it did in Civ 5. Suddenly he loves you. Then the next turn he's complaining you're putting down cities too close to him and your troops are at his border even though they haven't left yours. Next turn he wants to be friends. The turn after that he declares war. Ok?  - As I mentioned before religion is broken with the AI, so they will spam Apostles and missionaries faster than you can put them out. I had a game with religious faith generation and I couldn't keep up with any other civ. I would convert a bunch of cities and within 1-3 turns they were all converted back to the opposing religion. They'll rush 10 apostles to get this done.   - The districts are a neat idea, but even in 'online' speed the build times for many things are outrageous. The further into the tech tree you get the more production is required to get things up and running. In civ 5 there was a curve for some things (policies cost more with more cities, you need to build libraries to get oxford etc) but it's really steep here.   - The civilopedia has next to no information in it. Want to figure out how corps work? Good luck with that because you can't search for it.   - Give me black fog of war please.   This game has a lot of potential but what I just listed are a few examples of the many issues this game has. I suppose you can fault me for wishing it was more like civ 5, but it seems like they tacked on a host of new features without giving them much thought. Civilization 6 wants to be civilization 5, but like some rebel teenager it feels to be different without thinking about WHY the difference is better.

The game and its user interface are less complete than what I'd expect from a game going into release. As a programmer myself, I feel that I might have some special insight into this.  Starting with some of the higher impact ones: - It's harder to win in this civ. But that's most likely due to the fact, that my game crashes consistently on turn 220 in one specific save. - The game usually crashes on exit. - The AI relations seem to work somewhat awkwardly. Basically everyone's at war with everyone going into the 1900's at the latest. - The wartime unit control AI is inefficient. Although I wouldn't be as harsh, a fellow community member put it like this: 'I think Firaxis let the let the inexperienced interns build it'. - Ships can sometimes pathfind on land without any 'tyres for boats' tech whatsoever, even with full vision of the area in question. - Continents used to be my favorite map. This new terrain generator, however, is very 'sterile' in the sense that when it generates continents, there's never any imperfections like coastal islands. It's just a fixed amount of very large continents. Once you know where all the big continents are, there's no use exploring the oceans.  And some little things specific to one of my domain expertises, the user interface: - The pathfinding algorithm and the movement commands do sometimes not match. The unit doesn't follow it's pathfind guide. - Adding labels into the map is really useful in district planning. Unfortunately, deleting a label, followed by adding a new label causes the text of the new label to overwrite the one that was written earlier, while the new label remains empty. This is an example of something that's called an off-by-one mistake. It's often easy to correct, provided that it's actually found. - Any UI element that spawns underneath the cursor is unclickable until the user moves the cursor away from it and then back onto it. - Some of the state-machines for the UI-elements are broken. An example would be that an element cannot be activated until it's deactivated once before again trying to activate it. - Another instance of an off-by-one error is, when a city finishes building something and the related element doesn't show the building that was built, but the one that was built before that. - Switching the construction project for the city sometimes loses one element from the buildings list, and it's not the one that you just started constructing. In these cases, there's a building element in that list with graphics that seem to be cut off from the bottom. This is likely an off-by-one mistake as well. - It's impossible to switch from constructing a single unit to constructing an army, without selecting another construction project in between. - The complete information about what a wonder does, is not always available in the button to construct that wonder. - After a construction project has begun, it's impossible to find out what that building does without visiting the civilopedia.  That said, I do appreciate many of the game design choices made while going for this implementation of the franchise. Especially the combat mechanics, and the requirement for having to actually think a lot about where to build each district. Unfortunately I'll have to set the game aside for at least a few months, due to some of the larger issues affecting playability with the current release.

This game is different than Civ 5 in many ways. But i still enjoy it. There are new features, but some features have been removed. The happines system has been replaced by how many amenities you have. You can no longer just build anything in your city (with the exception of the initial few building like a granary), you now have to build certain centers to build certain things (i.e If you build an encampment, you can then build accademies, barracks and etc. Also units will spawn on the encampment first and then the city, meaning you can technically buy two millitary units per city per turn). However, you must be smart with the centers/districts. Each distric requires a tile to be built on. from then point on, each improvement made in the catagory of the district will be built on the tile of the district. Most Wonders also take up a tile now, meaning you can't have that one city that has a thousand wonders. Builders have also been changed. A builder will instantly build the desired improvement. However, they can only do so three times (this can be altered by wonders and government later in the game). In my opinion i enjoy that feature. I no longer have a thousand workers with nothing to do in mid to late game. A lot of people have been complaining that there is no difference in the A.I in the game compared to Civ 5. I beg to differ. The A.I acts very similar, but one big difference is that they are more likely to declare war on you and other civilizations. Granted they won't go all Gandhi on you and drop a million nukes, but this does make the game a bit more interesting. I like this because i'm no longer the only person to declare war on people. All in all, i enjoy the game.

This game has proven to be a major disappointment. Any strategy game of this nature must strike a balance between playability versus richness of detail. You want to be able to manage and control aspects of the game and develop a strategy, but you also want to revel in the pleasure of the simulation world that you are watching unfold and develop before your eyes. Unfortunately, the developers of this game decided to tilt the balance massively in favor of micromanagement, to the point where the joy of this game has been sucked out of it. Even the workers, now called 'builders', now must be micromanaged, along with the placement of every wonder and zone. Meanwhile, the horrible graphics--who came with the idea, anyway, of distinguishing between unexplored regions versus regions with no units nearby bu using two different shades of brown?--make it hard to get any kind of strategic overview of the world map. I don't expect the graphics to be earth shattering, but they should be pleasing and useful--and in this game, they are neither. And what's with the removal of so many default keyboard shortcuts, anyway? A major step down from Civilization V.

I tried to play some cooperative multiplayer with a friend of mine the day after launch. Things we realized, in order:      Cooperative multiplayer is not present at launch; they've ommitted team formation of any kind.     The UI is clumsy and buggy. Edge scrolling is so broken I've actually had to turn it off, which is a first for me in years. Trying to use a city ranged attack centres the view on the city, and the screen movement deselects the attack. The notifications (on the righthand side) are so itty-bitty and convey so little information visually that I very frequently miss them entirely.     Barbarians are always, always in 'Rage of the Gods' mode and you will generally have 5 or more units on your case within 20 turns.     Sean Bean was probably a bad choice for narration. He's no Leonard Nimoy. To be honest I would have preferred it if they had just brought in the same guy who narrated Civ V.     The ludicrous AI from Beyond Earth's awful expansion pack is back in full force. They will frequently get annoyed and declare war on you, and you won't be able to find out what their grievances are aside from 'They are upset because of an unknown reason -14 relationship points'. Diplomacy feels more flat and uninvolved than normal.     Remember how Civilization V had some really bad netcode that made multiplayer incredibly frustrating? Well, that's still present too. We got desychronized 7 times before we had reached turn 100.   I'm not recommending this game to anyone right now. It's not that I don't like the new gameplay; I've been a fan of this series for  20 years  now. I've played through changes before and been fine with them. I even like several of the new ideas this game has. But as it stands? This game just doesn't work on an objective level. Just a few hours in, I stopped playing Friday and haven't been able to bring myself to launch it again.  After turn 95, that friend I was playing with described it as 'About as polished as a rock in the middle of a meadow'. I'm going to go a step further and describe it as ' desperately unfinished '. If you're going to charge CDN$ 105 for the digital deluxe or CDN$ 80 for the normal release, for God's sake, make a product that  works .

City spam, from the days of yore, is back! There's no global happiness, and neither Science/Culture become more expensive with more citites. Thus, it's optimal to continuously build Settlers as long as there are any valid places to build a city. Don't worry about putting the city near luxury resources: the cities share them!  This sucks, and makes the game much less fun. That's my main complaint. Other, lesser complaints:  1. AI take their actions very slowly. Near the end of my game, each turn took a full 2.5 minutes. This is painful, especially when you're just hitting 'End Turn' a few turns in a row. 2. Leaders are not very diverse. Civ 5 had neat weird stuff like Venice, which completely changed the game. In Civ 6, each country has one slightly better building, and one slightly better military unit. Granted, this will likely improve over time with DLC. 3. In order to assign Fixed Teams from Multiplayer, you have to edit config files. Manageable, but sloppy.  I'll give credit where credit is due: there are a lot of good ideas in here. I love Districts, and I love Culture as a parallel research track. I like the new art style (haters gonna hate). But overall, a weak entry to the franchise. Stick with Civ 5 or Endless Legend.

It feels like a beta. There are gameplay imbalances, minor bugs, UI problems, and despite it's multiple paths to victory, following the path of least resistance narrows down viable choices significantly, to either military conquest or the space race. Many parts of this game are just flat-out frustrating. I've never dropped F-bombs while playing a Civ game before, that is not until I played Civ 6.   It's a good game, but who put Dark Souls in my Civ? This is easily the hardest and most complex Civ by far, and that's saying a lot. Graphics have a washed-out color palette which I don't like, but hey it's Civ I'm not playing it for the graphics.  Some new game mechanics ('housing' and 'appeal' I'm looking at you!) limit the speed of expansion and city growth and just make the game slower and harder, kind of like they limited city growth with Beyond Earth, which as we all know was not a well-received game (WTF why'd you put concepts from that crappy game in Civ 6?!?!).   I'm playing on Prince level which feels harder than King level in Civ V. Other leaders now seem markedly more aggressive and love to play nice then surprise attack (of course some are still pacifists, like Ghandi).  The biggest difficulty spike is with barbarians. I do NOT like the new barbarian system. Yes, I understand once a barbarian scout sees your city they'll send troops after you, so you need to eliminate their camp fast, but if you're unlucky enough to come across multiple camps early on, you're f u u u k t. Even a single camp will send WAAAAY too many troops very quickly, and even at the very beginning of the game they already have spearmen, horsemen, ranged units, etc that you have to fight with warriors, and they'll send up to 4-5 at a time, straight for your cities. Really?! At Prince level?! And then there've been a few games where I didn't see many barbarians at all. Yes there is an option to turn barbarians off, but why only on or off? Why not have an option for different levels of barbarian activity, like you did in the last few Civ games? I actually think some players (the same who love Dark Souls) will like the new barbarian mechanic, but the on/off only, with no in between really sucks.   That's how it is with many parts of Civ 6 - it's more complex than vanilla Civ V, but its customizability has been dumbed-down. You can no longer sculpt gameplay parameters to play the type of game you want to play, because the ability to tweak various gameplay aspects has been stripped.  As far as extra features compared to Civ V (note: I never played Civ V expansions), they throw everything but the kitchen sink at you. Some features are great, others not so much. You have civics with subset features, religion with subset features and a new type of religious 'currency' called faith, culture, city buildings, air/land/sea military and support units, espionage, science, trade routes (which now build your roads), diplomacy, a new feature for your cities called districts, housing (if you don't have enough, your city can't grow, and it's not easy to get more - not a good system please get rid of it!!!), resouce development, tourism, natural wonders, world wonders to build, the list goes on. Whew! If you like deep strategy you definitely have it here! Honestly it might be too much. Too many gameplay mechanics muddies everything up and dilutes the power of certain focused strategies and decisions.  The game seems to move slower than previous Civs. Maybe it's because the extra complexity means I'm spending more time doing more things each turn. But as a result that 'one more turn' feeling goes away after you're empire is big and requires lots of micromanaging. So I have mixed feelings. I think some changes are fantastic and others are really frustrating. I'm giving it a thumbs up because it's still the addicting Civ gameplay, but I STRONGLY recommend you watch some gameplay videos, reviews, etc. before buying this game because it won't appeal to everyone, even many past Civ fans. IMHO Civ is now SO complex and difficult, it's now a 'hardcore fans only' niche type game. If it's your niche, however, you will love it.
