The point of this game:  CIV 6 focuses heavily on the first X of the 4 X's (explore, expand, exploit, exterminate). The first 70 turns definitely take a lot longer than they used to with far more early threats to you, from barbarians to exploitative AIs who will warrior rush you if they catch even the faintet whiff of weakness. Exploring the land around you eventually leads to holding the space with a moderate sized army - then frantically pumping out settlers to yank as much of the surrounding land as possible before the AI gets it, setting you up for at least one conflict in the next 50 turns.   Here's my way of maximinizing the amount of fun I have with this game:  Bigger maps and more space to expand I find is more fun. On a small map with regular settings I find that I can settle maybe 3-4 cities and then the rest is conquering, which is sort of a bummer. I reccomend playing on at least standard size with low sea levels to increase settleable land. This lengthens the time that the early game takes, which honestly usually ends up being the most fun part. The rest is too easy.   The one, big problem:  The AI is unbelievably stupid. If video game AIs could write civ 6's AI would write youtube comments. Hopefully they fix this. Basically by the time we reach that first conflict we talked about the AI has either neglected gold or science so you're already 2-3 military tech levels ahead of them. Normally they DoW on you forst so you can eat their civ with only a small warmonger penalty and then just run away with the game.   The amount of fun you're going to have with this depends on:  The best predictor of this game is whether you enjoyed past CiV games. If you enjoy economic/other resource management games that's another good sign. I like most of the changes in this game (distrits, wonders, etc.), I just wish I could stop steamrolling the AI effortlessly if I make it past the first 120 turns.

I wouldn't recommend this game in its current form. It needs some pretty hard tweaking on the numbers for it to be a viable game. Certainly the gameplay of every iteration of the civilization franchise has changed from the previous one, but in this version there are many things that are lacking.  1. The AI. The ai is often incredibly dumb. They couldn't fight their way out of a paper bag. The number of suprise wars is staggering, yet making peace is just as easy. You are constantly inundated with the AI's 'advice' about your country, but soon these screens are annoying as they take up too much time.  2. The production costs. In the game units/buildings/districts take way too long to produce. I'm playing on the 'online' speed (double the speed of the normal game) and it still takes forever. The cost of districts is simply too high, it feels like players need to be focus on hammers/production much more than ever before.  3. The interface is just bad. The mouse over to expand elements is finicky at best and downright frustrating at worst. The game will NOT let you do things out of order easily. When I'm in the middle of waging a war I want to go focus on managing units, not being FORCED to pick science and production for my cities first (and sometimes you are FORCED to deal with certains things at certain times regardless of what you want.) Additionally, the diplomacy screens drone on and on, and even getting to the menu to click through them takes a long time. I LOVED them at first, the animation quality and emotive content was great, but now it's tiring to have to wait so long.  Overall civ 6 feels like a bad move, it seems like they took the idea that a game of civilization should last a long time and turned it up to 11, in a BAD way. Things take way too long, the interface is confusing, there is a conspicuous lack of options to alleviate these minor problems, and the game just feels unpolished. I play games to relax, and I only have a limited amount of free time to play them. It's frustrating when it seems like someone designed a game to take a long time on purpose, not designed an awesome well paced game I want to spend a lot of time playing.
That 'Just one more turn...'-feeling. It just aint there. At this point Civ V is superior in every way to this game, such a shame... Patch it up, doc!

tl;dr Girlfriend is out of town, forget fapping I'm just gonna play civ 6. Best civ ever. Minor bugs/gameplay issues.  For a game that was just launched the other day, it plays well. I don't have the best gaming computer, but I can run it close to max regardless. My graphics card is Nvidia 745 compared to the suggested 770. I did turn off anti analyzing and lowered shadow resolution. Neither of which are noticeable. Load times are kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥ if you don't have a solid state drive, but they're tolerable without one. UI makes sense and scales to the screen correctly for the most part. Minor UI glitches here and there (Stuff overlapping each other. Next turn/open close a menu fixes it.) but it's nothing that can't be ignored.   The biggest complaint I can make is how war civs use open borders. It's only war civs that bother me. There's a new feature called districts, you can read about it in the description. Anyways, they are vital for great people and you must have your great person on the tile the district is on to use it. AI civs love to sit on important tiles forever. Even if they're your ally they will sit there. It's not that the AI is trying to hurt you, it's that it doesn't realize it is. Sometimes when you give open borders to a war civ that doesn't like you, they'll flood you with their troops. I believe they're trying to actually attack you but were not coded to start a war by attacking a city. Only by passing the borders. I've had 20-30 troops in my border than when open borders ended they all left, and he declared war on me the next turn. Really annoying, but was manageable.    All the negatives aside, this is easily the best civ game. I've played hundreds of turns and still have yet to actually win. This is coming from a player who was able to play higher difficulties online on civ 5. It's different, but in a good way. It's refreshing. A lot of the civs have been the same ol' wait 30 turns to do anything. In my experience, there are only short wait times before something interesting happens. Whether it's a city state kicking your ♥♥♥ (Yes, they're more robust now.) or Gandhi actually being Gandhi and sharing his religion, something is happening. To me, it always felt that the only fun speed online was quick so you could actually experience an age or two. With this release, we've been playing longer games, and they feel good.  City states were something I never utilized in Civ 5. I'd rather just pump my money into my cities rather than those jerks who didn't even help that much. Civilization 6 introduced a where you can add a 'point' to a city-state to gain a little bit more control over it. They're actually useful enough that I have yet to play one game where I didn't try to get a few. Also, the game helps you get them in a non-forceful way. Kind of like accumulating faith, it's a little dial that fills up and once full gives you one point. Other civs will compete to get these city states. So ensure you're supporting the ones that will help your win condition the most.  New win condition: Religion. Adding this win condition they removed diplomatic victory. Now, you can properly start a crusade. Other civs will recognize that you are doing a holy crusade, and you're not just warmongering. You have a true reason that a war needs to happen to make the balance exist. If you spread your religion to every civ, with your religion being their dominant one, you win. Simple as that. It's a new play style that feels good. Gandhi plays the best, in my opinion, have had the most success with him. Arabia was pretty good too. But I've yet to try all the civs still.  I know I'm forgetting something. I'm sure I'll edit this review. Also, I'd like to point out that I'm writing all this not even 72 hours after launch. I'm sure a lot of the problems that exist will be removed as time goes on.   Overall: Highly recommend. I might as well uninstall civ 5 now.

Well, I am fairly new to Sid Meier's Civilization games in general but what I can say from playing a handful of hours in Civilization V and playing a few hours (so far) of Civilization VI is that they are both very well done games. Some may say that Civilization VI is just a re-skinned version of the previous Civilization V but I beg to differ with the help of some people and friends around me.  The district systems are a new feature that Sid Meier and the team at 2K and Firaxis have implemented into Civ. Districts require you to pre-plan and think ahead which calls for some more thinking and skill rather than just clicking a selected building like in Civ V.  Wonders work in a way that you must, again, put thought into because in the middle to late game, you will have limited areas where you can build your wonders and the overall city condition can be drastically effected if one makes a decision poorly.  These are two fairly important changes to the game that will either make or break your gaming experience.   Now on the contrary I would like to say that I am really not a fan on how the aesthetic map works in Civilization VI. In Civilization V you have the basic 'Fog of War' or clouds that conceal an area that is yet to be discovered, however in Civilization VI you have this pretty yet annoying old, rustic map look. You may not see any problem with this but hear me out. Back in Civilization V, the map will just become darker when you no longer have sight in a certain area but you can still see the land in detail. Now in Civilization VI you have the world turn back to a 'drawing' of the world which looks very similar to the areas where you haven't explored. This may be as easy as getting used to it but I feel that its not the best.  Thats all from me but I would still recomend this game 7.8 nukes out of 10 nukes.

This is a great addition to the franchise. Newly implemented gameplay mechanics, such as a division between the civics and technology trees along with boost bonuses towards civics and technologies for completing associated actions/projects, adds a new level of immersion and depth to to an otherwise familiar system. It is also worth noting that the improved Civics/Tech system is a major component in alleviating the previously tedious mid-game. The addition of building districts onto your cities is also a much appreciated component that allows players to spread a city across multiple tiles. Interaction with AI leaders has also been improved by adding an 'agenda' system of punishment and rewards corresponding to the player's choices.   It is worth noting that, at the time of this review, there are a number of launch-day bugs that have yet to be patched. Nothing game-breaking at this point, but still enough to be an annoyance. Also, I have to admit my biggest complaint is the current lack of single player scenarios, which I found to be particularly enjoyable in Civilization V. Multi-player functionality, aside from options that allow for more stringent control of game length, are nothing new, which I find to be a positive aspect. Civilization V had a highly successful and dedicated community of online players to which Civilization VI is poised to continue and expand.   As for value, I find that the $60 price tag is more than justifiable considering the sheer amount of gameplay by hours you have the opportunity to experience solely in the base vanilla game. That being said, I am eagerly awaiting the expanded roster of civilizations, scenarios, and gameplay mechanics to be found in future additions. Additionally, the soon to be implemented full mod support, which also had a highly talented and dedicated following in Civilization V, offers an almost limitless potential to enhance and expand upon the base game. Considering this, the total amount of play time per dollar spent is only going to improve as these aspects are implemented.  Bottom line, those familiar with the series will find plenty here to provide ample amounts of challenge, intrigue, and entertainment. Those new to the series will find the same, but also may experience a bit of a learning curve, particularly on higher difficulty levels. Lower difficulty level are perfect for learning, and the game provides an excessively detailed tutorial option on the main menu if lack of familiarity is a concern for you. Overall, Civilization Vi is true to its core, while intelligently innovating many areas that were in need of improvement. I highly recommend this game.

It amuses me to no end all of the people complaining about this game.  Even without any DLC Civilization VI is an improvement on nearly every aspect of Civilization V. Unstacking the cities is brilliant & adds depth to game play, as well as requiring you to plan out your civ's development. From terrain features, to adjacency bonuses, to what wonders you might want to build, everything has to be considered; as you can't simply spam every building & wonder into a mega city or two.   The Civic's Tree & Tech Tree are both impacted by the actions that you undertake, making your cvis development in both effected by what you've done previously. The different forms of government allow for different numbers of policy types to be adopted, along with providing specific bonuses that can dramtically effect how your civilization operates.   Great people are dramatically improved, as each great person provides different benefits & bonuses, rather than each being essentially the same character with a different name. & you are given not only the possibility to purchase these great people with faith or gold, but to pass on a certain great person, if you think the next one will benefit you more. Something that is very important, now that every scientist, engineer, merchant, etcetera is different.   Influence with city states are no longer procured by simply dumping gold coins on them, but by investing envoys, a unique diplomatic currency with them. With the removal of world congress, you can't simply spam city state votes to a diplomatic victory by simply throwing enough gold at them. Yet your alliances with these city states can still greatly impact your civilization, providing resources, military assets, & additioanl benefits based upon the city state in question, as well as the policies you've adopted.  Military tactics are greatly improved via the creation of combining units of the same types or combining combat units with support units as both enhance unit performance. Legitimate secondary defenses are created by military districts that provide additional defense to civilizations, especially if due consdieration is given to terrain features & positioning. & the promotion tree for each unit is clearly layed out, so players can play what traits to focus on for each respective unit. Not to mention being able to name your units if they gain enough status, is a rather nice touch.  Put simply, ignore the haters, Civilization VI is brilliant, & the nay sayers can go back to playing COD or angry birds according to their respective preferences.

The barbarians are much smarter and more capable in combat. They advance in technology much faster. City tiles get used by zones rather than getting trading posts or forts. Played an individual campaign and came to the following conclusions:  - Gameplay is obviously similar to Civilization V - Graphics have been altered with slight adjustments to mechanics. - Districts have been introduced which is a new mechanic allowing combination of constructions into one tile instead of city based like that of V. - Amenities and Housing are essential; the need to build is a consistent factor throughout the game, more so than fortifying through armies. - HUD has become more complex, but after reading through some articles about the game became very clear how to operate the new mechanics established in the HUD.  All in all, the game has become slightly more complex with the ideal to allow the player to become more engulfed in the actual run of a city. Civ VI takes the tried-and-true formula of Civ V and alters it in some promising ways. The addition of disticts, the civics tree, religious victories, and more goverment types are welcome. In particular, I like how the system of unit promotions has been changed. Tactical combat feels well-balanced and an improvement over Civ V. Civ VI also succeeds in streamlining the midgame, whereas it was easy to feel stagnant and bogged down in Civ V. The cartoon graphics are nothing special, but nor are they ugly. Meanwhile, the sleek aesthetic of the menu screens is pretty cool.    However, my positive recommendation of Civ VI comes with an important caveat: I assume Firaxis will patch some of the game's current flaws. Namely, diplomacy. The AI is absurdly hostile to human players and not sophisticated enough for hidden agendas to feel like anything more than an obstacle. Having a different type of government (a likely situation, given that there are 10 types) is also a major hindrance to peaceful relations. During my first 26 hours of gameplay on Prince difficulty, at no point was any AI civ anything other than 'unfriendly,' 'denounced,' and 'at war.' Strangely, human players quickly incur warmonger penalties even when they are not the aggressors. Introducing casus belli seems like a neat idea, but diplomacy needs to be massively re-balanced before such a system becomes worthwhile.   There are also a few minor glitches and buggy features to consider. For instance, sometimes when hovering one's cursor over a side menu, the dialog box for the terrain tile behind the cursor will still appear. Sometimes units will obscure the ranged attack option of a city or fortification. And the map is cluttered that (even in strategy view) it's easy to misclick and send the wrong unt to the wrong location. On the whole though, these are not at all game-breaking and I trust that Firaxis will patch some of the more annoying ones.   Conclusion: Worthy of the Sid Meier's name and worth buying now if you liked Civ V, but still in need of improvement.

Civ6 has a lot of potential. You can love or hate the new graphic, but overall, it works pretty well. And let's be honest - Civilization was never a game you played because of the graphics.  The new features are very promising as well. The new city districts are very interesting, and the re-design of technological and cultural advances in two similar, but separate trees add a lot to the game as well.  The technological and cultural boosts are also hugely interesting, as they add more decisions to the game. Do I develop this new technology right now, as I could really need the benefits it brings? Or will I develop something else first, and wait until I have earned the boost for that technology, cutting its development time in half?  So in a nutshell, Civ6 is Civ5 with a few very promising new features.  But then, why do I not recommend it? The 2 reasons have been mentioned in many other reviews already, and I can only emphasize them.  1) The AI is abysmal. It may be 'A', but it most definitely isn't 'I'. It acts so unbelievably stupid that it just does not provide a challenge. Only in the highest difficulty setting, it gets so many boosts that it provides a challenge for scientific or cultural victories. But in terms of military conflicts, it acts laughable at best, on all levels. The AI in Civ5 was not too great already, but the AI of Civ6 is much, much worse.  2) Bugs. Tons of bugs. Most of them small ones, but still annoying.  Buildings disappear from cities. The 'finished production' display is broken entirely and never shows the thing your city just finished producing. AI military units disappear. City states give you a quest to build a specific unit, but that quest doesn't finish when you build the unit (probably a result of the 'finished production' bug mentioned before). Convoys don't work. Units are displayed in the wrong location (i.e., they are indeed one hex, and the game knows it, but they are displayed 10 hexes away, caught in an infinite 'running animation' loop). Trade is broken. I ask the AI what it wants for a specific luxury ressource, It asks for 8 gold per round. I refuse and make a counter-offer of 4 gold. The AI refuses. I ask what would fix the deal. The AI now demands 2 gold per round and loves me for accepting the deal. The game tells me than an unmet player has been eliminated. Several times. But when I keep exploring, I meet all civilizations that were supposed to be in the game. Diplomacy is broken entirely.  I could go on for hours. This was obviously a rushed release, that leaves a strong 'early-access' aftertaste. It was more important to publish the game well in time for Christmas, rather than releasing a finished product.  Again, the potential is there, and I honestly hope that I can amend my review at some point.  But if you are to decide whether to buy the game right now, or to wait for the first sale discount, then my advice is to go for the latter. Chances are that, at the time it goes on sale, you will receive a much better game than you'd get right now.

(Reasons below.) Conclusion (for now): Don't come looking for a Civ V experience, you won't find it here. The game has been drastically changed on a lot of fronts. Graphic-wise, I personally really had to get used to it and still do though a lot of nuisances I had with Civ V and graphical clipping have been removed. I think I can eventually enjoy this game more (I have already, but it hasn't gripped me from the start like Civ V), it hasn't blown my mind and I wouldn't recommend it for 60-80 bucks, hence the negative review. Consider purchasing when it is 30-40 for the base game and 40-50 for the digital deluxe. (Or less. I'd refund it if I could and likely repurchase it later down the line for less.) This game definitely is NOT perfect contrary to what other reviews make you think, hell, I'm leaning to believe it is a step backwards for the Civ franchise. Gone are the glory parts that made me want to stand the test of time.  So.. What can I put down about it in this short timeframe. I'll compare things to what I'm used to in Civ V as that's the game that got me really hooked on the series.  + No technical issues whatsoever. + Less graphical clipping and overall cleaner state of the game. Roads look nice, bridges look nice. Wonders and natural wonders are quite pretty. You can actually see buildings being build and adding to your city or districts. + Traders. I really like how they go out and build roads, give a line of sight through the fog of war areas. + New combat animations. Not all are mind-blowing, but for instance, destroying a cavalry unit shows the soldier falling off the horse and the horse running off. I thought it was a nice touch. + Scouts get upgrades for exploring around the map. A mod I've used for a while for Civ V so was really happy with that myself. + Envoys in city states. I really like this touch and the bonus they provide, it really feels like you build up to a bigger and better city-state ally over time, later on you can even use gold to gain temporary control over their units. (Which should in theory, help reduce the issue of the city-state being useless in a war like Civ V. It rarely if ever send its units to fight the enemy.) + Narrating for technologies. I like it, pleasant voice, interesting text. + Unit promotions. Less options and simpler, but nicer overall and easier to plan ahead since you can see all of them when you promote a unit.  +/- No more ruins, settlements instead or so I'm led to assume. I haven't seen any ruins and while visiting friendly tribes is nice on its own, Civ V had me going on that 'will you stand the test of time' idea to which ruins really fit. I'd have liked to see settlements and ruins or perhaps a mechanic of barbarians visiting settlements first, so they -become- ruins. +/- Opening cutscene / main menu sound track, some love it. I'm not blown away by it but it isn't bad. They added an option to skip the opening cutscene in the options which is neat. +/- Leader overlay. They have seen several improvements to animations and the voices aren't bad, though the screen when heading into the game has been almost completely robbed off history and accomplishments like you had detailed in Civ V. Once picking a civilization and heading in-game (so after load, just before going in-game), you can't see the unit details or special building traits like you could when hovering your mouse on it, and yet there's plenty of space to have included all of that in. I'd have liked more narrating like it did in Civ V. +/- In-game music, unit movement animation; I feel these two combined give the game a really 'serene' touch in ways. I find it relaxing, to the point where I feel it becomes.. Too slowed down? It looks nice, it sounds nice, but unit movement doesn't have the same 'swiftness' to it that Civ V had. +/- Graphics overall. A lot looks nice, rocky edges on ocean tiles look absolutely fantastic but the combination of everything may feel ever so slightly 'young' or 'childish'. I don't hate it, it looks clean, it looks crisp, it is new and different but I'm not sold on them yet. They really take some getting used to. I may simply be too used to how Civ V looks.  - Removed right-clicking on 'next turn' to skip over a supposed assigment. (Such as envoys.) You have to open the entire message, exit it again, then you can go to the next turn. Tedious, slows gameplay down even further. - Can't restart the game with the same settings on the first turn when you for instance, dislike your starting location. Have to go through all menus/settings again. - Early game, the game is even more slowed down. Production is hard to get, citizens are acquired rather slowly. The first ~150 turns you do nothing but selecting research, selecting a policy and hitting next while exploring the map. This is nothing new, but it has gotten even worse. No chance for say acquiring rams early on and capturing a city-state or city. I've yet to receive a troop upgrade from a settlement so I think those are removed too. You'll only get a scout at best from them unit-wise. - No renaming cities, no renaming Civ's. Units can be renamed after earning two promotions which is really strange though they added a random title generator for them. - Barbarian AI is dumb. Like really dumb. The barbarians can surround your city and casually sit there on prince difficulty. They will not ever attack, they will not pillage or become a nuisance like they were in Civ V. (Sometimes overly so.) At one point I had my city surrounded by 3 barbarians and they continued to sit there as if it was open-bar night; I casually made a slinger and began throwing rocks at their faces for the next couple of turns. When I killed two the last one finally ran off. (And then I killed that one too to make a statement.) They had mines to pillage two tiles away in my kingdom, farms to pillage, a trader to capture. They did none of that.   Furthermore, barbarians can't make proper decisions on how to move horses and will often move the same two tiles back and forth for a few turns in a row. Their barbarian warriors either purely fight randomly or select the highest-HP unit meaning that if they could potentially kill a low-HP soldier of yours, they won't go for it when there's another unit nearby. - Civs are even quicker to anger; They will hate you for exploring more of the map then them, they will hate you for acquiring a great person or because you got a luxery resource they don't. It is like the Devs didn't want you to play the game so the AI declares war on you for playing the game. - Some things will leave you confused and feel unintuitive. Cities not being able to attack anymore before you build a wall in them for instance. (This may be a thing from the older games. I did not really touch those much.) - Wonders while looking pretty, don't feel impactful. I build the hanging gardens only to scratch my head on completion going 'Wait, what does that do again?'. I mean, I can guess as I played Civ V but instead of adding the information to the overlay screen like it they did in Civ V, you simply see it getting build now and looking pretty. I'd like to have seen the information added upon completion. (Like it was in Civ V)  ? Multiplayer maps seem scarce, though I genuinely don't recall how it was anymore with Civ's V release. May have been more, may have been less. Missing an earth map, skirmish, north vs south and things like that. ? Some AI always seem to die very early on no matter the game. I've had two AI die in a six player game on turn 68.  ? Diplomacy systems, districts, housing, water, etc. I've yet to fully grasp these mechanics and have no real opinion on it yet. ? Religion Pantheon choices don't.. seem useful like, at all or incredibly minor. Not sure if it is worth pursuing a religion at all. They have been severely narrowed down from Civ's V options.

That's not to say the game is 100% perfect. I'd like to see bonus resources factor into the new Amenity system, & I'd like to see multiple copies of the same luxury and/or strategic resource have some kind of point (beyond foreign trade)-indeed, I'd like to see luxury and strategic resources work in very much the same way as strategic resources worked in Civ5.  The Civics Tree, District System, Eurekas/Inspirations, truly novel City States and Great People and the government system are all truly brilliant IMHO. If anyone is new to Civ, I'm sure you'll love the game whole-heartedly.  If you've played Civ before, you may well have a few complaints. Most of these complaints from people I've seen are, 'It plays differently'.  Overall the game is great, interesting new ways to play. The limited builders, which many are whining about, is just fine as it means they're actually important and you don't just slap out a few and forget them. The graphics are obviously going to be down to personal preference. The pictures don't do it justice, in motion it looks better than the static images. Having said that, the designs do look more like Civilisation: Revolution. I do think the graphics is something many can't accept because they see it as a mirror of simplification, which the game has not done.   In all, it's a new way to play a great game.  However, this is the negative part that I do find irritating;  As with the original Beyond Earth you get the other leaders show up and complain or compliment you. There's a little animation, which is nice, but silence. No speaking. They just wiggle at you or smile at you and say something that you will probably find irrelevant, such as 'your culture growth is good'. They interrupt your game just to tell you this! In Beyond Earth: Rising Tide it was removed and changed to small boxes at the top of the screen that would show every now, approving or disappoving of your actions. This was much, much better! And yet, here on Civ 6, they've reverted to the original, annoying system of interrupts.  I hope this irritation is removed and replaced as it was with Beyond Earth.

(Under editing as I play) Ok, I'm really enjoying this game, but if you've already got a copy of Civ 5 with most of the DLC, I would think about whether it's worth switchg at the current price (I've just changed this to a postive review). As a rough estimate I'd say it's 25% different, and the differences became more apparent as I went on. If you feel the cost is pocket change, then absolutely buy it; otherwise you might want to hold out for 6 month to a year until it's cheaper- it's your call. I personally love a whole new set of achievements to meet and new mechanics to learn, but the gameplay experience is really putting it in the 'similar yet different' category.   If you're new to the franchise than I absolutely recommend the game- it's a lot of fun and holds many of the features of the last game with DLC, while adding some new ones. If you enjoy other strategy games like Age of Empires, SimCity, Crusader Kings, Europa Universalis then it's definately worth giving Civ 6 a shot. Most of this review will be focusing on how it's different to Civ V though.  Pros: -I really like the mechanic that gives you a boost to your research or culture (civics tree) if you've already completed a given task (it differs for each one). It's great and really makes sense. I found it changing how I chose the next thing to move on to depending on the likelihood that I'd complete the boost anytime soon. - Diplomacy seems to be better. Sure Gandhi still love his nukes, but it's very clear that this is the case (long running joke), rather than it seeming like a bug. I've so far found that the characters conform to their agendas more after just one game then they ever did in Civ V. Why Gandhi refused to accept my embassy/delegations when we had a decent neutral relationship remains a mystery however. - Easy to learn and get into. (I'm coming from a Civ 5 background, so not sure how intuitive it would otherwise be) It still however adds new concepts and challenges that are interesting to a veteran of the games. Hope that appeal will last, but I'm too new to it still in order to make a fair call. -I really like the information system later in the game. You actually get too much information and have to try and look for patterns in it to see if you can get a sense of the strategies the other players are using. - The great person system is much more realistic and I think will lead to more in depth strategy to get the ones you want. You are actually competing for the attention of each great person with the other cultures and each one seems to provide unqiue benefits. For example, your Industraial era great scientist offers different benefits to the information era one. - You have different government types available to you throughout most of the game. There are three 'stages' each with three different options that allow you to customise the benefits your society receives. It's a good expansion of the ideology mechanism in Civ V.  Cons: - My first game I was going for a science victory and was working on building the space districts. I get a video take up my screen and think that I've lost and there are achievements related to loosing because they're popping up on the side of my screen like crazy... Nope, I won a culture victory without even noticing or being told that I was close... I was only on Prince difficulty to get used to it, but I found this a little strange. - There was a stage in the early game where I got really bored (about 1 hour and 10 mins in) and I was looking like I was going to ask for the 2 hour refund. It did improve later though - It still takes too long in between turns. Sure I played the first game through with the combat and movements on just to see what they're like, but it doesn't seem any faster which is one of the things I was most hoping would be fixed. - Movement for units takes much longer than previously. In Civ V you could go across a field before going into a forest in one turn, now it take 2 turns as if either of the terrains require you to slow down it now takes the whole turn. This really makes sense- it was strang how it worked before, but it does make the fighting with all the barbarians stage drag a lot. And there are way more Barbarians -I'm not the biggest fan of the art style; though I'm used to it now. I feel that it should feel a little bit more provincial and realistic, but I do find it quite functional. I totally disagree with views saying that it makes it like a simple mobile game. It's different than before (and you do want change with a new game), and do see some of the benefits it brings with easier identification -I had a message saying I had discovered a coal site, however it wasn't clear at all, and it was actually under one of my districts. I was receiving all of the benefits from it, but I wasted a fair amount of time until I was able to figure this out. - If someone finishes a wonder before you do, even if you've been working at it for many turns and are almost done.... well nothing... No credit, no money, no compensation.. it's all just a waste... (Writing the review as I play you get smallish comments like this) - I start negotiating on a trade that I don't realise is really favourable to me. I change anything and suddenly not only is all they were offering me in addition is gone, a 'fair' trade of resources is no longer acceptable... WTF? (It's actually much worse than in Civ V- This needs to be fixed- or the screen where you see what they're offering needs to at least be big enough to see everything) - The icon saying ... has declared war on ... etc is a bit buggy. It'll be clear for the first one that pops up, but if there are more than one, usually with city state involvement, it's a bit hard to figure out what's going on as the second to 6th notifications don't always work so well. Would be better if on provided a summary of declarations of war in that turn when you clicked on it. - Ok, I like that the quotes change. i just got one from Courtney Cox though... Yeah, can we stick to slightly more profound quotes. Keep it up to date as you get into later eras absolutely, and if the quote was related to entertainment or culture, fair enough, but it was for a scientific laser discovery. Unless I'm really misssing something, that's kinda an insult to modern scientists... 'I'll be back' for Robotics, however = Gold.  Overall:  I think it's a worthwhile game. The price tag is kinda high if you've already got Civ 5 with most of the DLC, as the experience isn't really that different, but it's still been an enjoyable experience so far. This will probably change to a positive review as I play and explore the differences more and get more used to the different mechanics. My initial review after 10+ hrs of gameplay. Background: Dedicated but casual player of every Civ since the first. Score so far: 8.5/10  Bottom line: It's fairly similar to Civ V, but different and interesting enough to warrant a new version. Some new interesting dynamics have been introduced, and religion is back.   Pros:  +Districts. This is the main difference between in Civ VI and all other versions. Now, many upgrades to your city actually are located on a district tile outside of the city square. This adds new levels of location strategy.  +Units. The unit gameplay is similar to Civ V, which I thought was an upgrade from doomstacks of earlier versions. Now, though, great generals can stack with regular units and support units to have 3 things on one tile. This is a good compromise.  +There are two full skill trees now. Technology, and Civics. In Civ V, the civics tree was a mini-tree. There are various ways to get 'Boosts' to research by means of meeting certain mini-objectives, which include researching something on the other tree, building X number of specific unit types or city improvements, or defeating an enemy unit with a certain type of unit. Now, it's not feasible to hide behind walls and spam science.  +Music. Always a strength of the Civ games, the music is well done. In Civ VI, the music you hear is based on the culture of the empire you choose, the scientific age you're in, and the other civilizations you meet. My first game was Rome, and early on I met America. So added to the traditional Roman themed music was some pleasant banjo bluegrass, which kinda worked, considering 'America' didn't exist in the ancient era. Later on, after I built my caravels and explored other continents, the sounds of Norway, Germany, India, and Japan were added to my soundtrack. It gets pleasantly quite grandiose in the Industrial Age. The only caveat is I wish they had more situational music, ie, more martial music while you're at war. It doesn't feel right to have some serene music playing while Rome's Legions are on the march! Of course, though, I'm sure the novelty of the music will wear off after dozens of hours, and eventually I'll probably end up muting the music and listening to other stuff while I play, but that should take a while.  +Graphics. This is a tricky one. This will be in the Pro and Con column. But as for the Pro, it's detailed and creates distinctiveness. Problems with earlier Civs is that by the modern era, all the tiles look very similar because of how the workers improved the land. Now, with the Districts and varied ways the land is worked, the landscape looks very different as you pan across the map. The map itself is nice, showing art in Terra Incognito, and displaying as an aged map in the Fog of War area, where there is no longer any visibility. This is an upgrade from gray an black. As an unadvertised interesting option, you can also turn on a day/night cycle in the game settings. It adds an interesting graphical variance over time, and even in a small war I haven't turned it off out of concern of being able to discern things properly at 'night.'  Cons -Graphics. Despite the praise above, it just looks cartoony. From what I've been reading, it's by far the biggest complaint people have with the game, and feels like a regression from earlier Civs. Even in the cinematics, it looks like they're characters from Frozen. Civ is not alone in this approach, as many games have gone to the 'stylized' approach, a trend that emerged with Warcraft III, I'd say.  -Less available info. It feels like when I want the data or lists of things I used to be able to have before, I can't find it. Is there a unit list? What happeneed to all the cool timeline data charts that every Civ has had?  -Religious combat & victory. I like that there is Religious combat, but opponents just spam apostles and try to roflstomp their religion for the win. Ghandi is on the verge of winning this way because he dominated his continent and I dominated mine, but then he pulled a religious normandy, storming my beaches with waves of zealous Hindu apostles, which don't need any permission to enter my territory or incur any negative for doing so. I have mostly repelled the horde, but it's touch and go. After seeing this system in play, I like the concept of it, but it needs tweaking. I don't think there should be a religious victory option. And, especially in more modern ages, there should be the development of non-religious populations, or reducing the gameplay effect of religion in the modern era and beyond.  -Price. It's $60. I would have expected to see $50 at launch. If the price is an issue for people - and I don't blame them at all if it is - wait for the Steam Winter Sale. It should be on sale then. All I can say is that I am pleased with the purchase at this point, which is FAR different from my disappointing experience with Civ: Beyond Earth.  As I continue playing, I will provide updates. Thanks for reading, and I appreciate any constructive feedback.

***AS I PLAY I AM UPDATING THIS REVIEW***  ***THIS IS THE MOST UPDATED REVIEW***   Quick Summary/ Analysis- This game is pretty damn good. My first game was rough, but that was simply becuase I had no idea of really what I was doing. However, once you get the hang of amenities (happiness), housing (population room), and the tech/civic trees (science & culture) then the game is a boatload of fun and you can really get immersed into the game. There's a tutorial if you want to be taught, but I ignored it as I prefer to teach myself through trial and error. Eventually, you have a general idea of what you're supposed to build and research, but the general timings and the overall importance involved with building & researching takes a little while longer to get use to since there are so many buildings, wonders, and districts. Workers also now have a limited amount of uses, build improvements instantly, and can no longer build roads. The game has some serious leg room for improvement and for more awesome content in the future (DLC and mods). I played the crap out of Civ 5 (1293 hours) and when it came out, it wasn't nearly as optimized or complete as Civ 6 has been so far during its release, so that makes this game all the more promising; although Civ 5 turned out pretty darn good.   Graphics and Audio-  I personally like the graphics style a lot, I wouldn't go as far as to say that I love it but it's a nice change from Civ 5 in my opnion. However, it is important to note that the game has a sense of a 'cartoony' type graphic style that will take a few hours or minutes (it depends on the person) to get used to. The soundtrack is very good and changes slighty throughout the game to keep things abstract and not so stail. Every leader has their own country-themed music that seems to suit quite nicely with all the civs I have tried so far (America, England, and France). This makes me assume that the others Civs will have good soundtracks as well, but I will update that with confirmation after I play all the other civs.  Leader bonuses and A.I.-  The leader's different bonuses seem to be fairly well balanced, however there are still a few Civs who are significantly better than others (Which is to be expected). The A.I. is fun to play against but sometimes still makes some absurd decisions (like building wonders instead of troops when I'm about to take their capital after I already took their other two other main cities), but still is good enough to provide not only a learning experience but also a decent challenge. If you want a true challenge though, you should be playing online against other players since humans always provide more of a challenge than the A.I; except for Deity. The A.I. is a decent opponent, but they are suceptable to early wars and large late game wars. They sometimes will settle right next to your capital in the early game instead of near their own capital for no obvious reason. It seems to me that the A.I. does this to either drive you into an early war and make you fall behind or to try and force you to take his city that's bordering your capital and frame you to make you look like a warmonger. The A.I. is improved over Civ 5 A.I. for sure, but they definitely still make some noticeable irrational decisions that have severe consequences (for them), even at high-tier difficulties such as Immortal and Deity.  War- War seems to be more focused on unit positioning, terrain, and your level of technology than ever before. War also lasts longer and feels similar to Civ 5 combat, but a little bit more refined in regards to the impact of terrain modifiers (which makes war more realistic). You may build encampments which are like military bases that can serve to shoot like a city or garrison units in like a fort, and in turn that provides a unique defensive aspect to the game and a nice aesthetical appeal around your cities as well. There are variety of units from archers and spearmen to thermonuclear warheads and rocket artillery. Additonally, there is even a new feature called 'corps' and 'armies' which are unlocked with the appropriate corresponding technologies. 'Corps' comes first and it allows you to have two of the same military units stacked on top of eachother on one single tile to form a more powerful & formidable, yet singular unit. 'Armies' are unlocked after corps and is simply an upgrade to corps because it allows you to stack up to three military units of the same type in one tile instead of merely two. You may also now bomb and destroy tiles, improvements, and districts with aircraft for added realism and additonal detriment to your opponet's economy and infrastructure.  Wonders & Workers-  Wonders are no longer built in the cities themselves but rather on a tile itself with special placement properties such as being adjacent to certain tiles/districts or being located on or near a certain tile (flood plain, grassland, desert, etc). One tile per wonder, but the tile needs speical attributes/districts. This means that wonder spamming is less prevelant and also dedicates more space of your empire to your wonders; so you can't build improvements on those tiles, but you can admire them and your Civ with an insurmountable amount of glory, admiration, and pride like never before. Workers can no longer build roads and instead roads are created via trade routes to and from cities in which the road is gradually built as the trade caravan ventures across the land to its final destination. Workers also have a limited amount of uses, can improve tiles instantly, and can aid in district and wonder construction.   Multiplayer- I have not played multiplayer yet, and therefore I cannot comment on it other than I recommend multiplayer to anyone who wants a challenge to test out their strategic mind and methods against another human; which in turn is better because we humans can analyze complex situations and algorithims while creating the appropriate responses to rectify those situations/algorithims. This also happens to be something that modern-day A.I.'s simply cannot do and are also severely lacking compared to human intelligence.   Final Purchasing Advice and Opinions- I recommend this game as it is very fun, immersive, well optimized and full of content that is definitely worth 60$. Unfortunately 60$ is a lot of money for some people so I can also recommend to wait until the game is on sale (like the winter or spring sale) that way you don't have to pay full price and then you may also play the game once the minor bugs have been ironed out and the modding community is up and running for Civ VI. I recommend this game to anyone who liked Civ 5 or is new to Civ in general, but like I also said, I highly recommend to wait until the price comes down in the future unless money is not a problem for you! Have an urge to rule the world? Or maybe you simply like history, strategy, and managing nations/armies, whichever it may be you will not regret buying this game! Good luck my fellow strategians.   P.S. Trade with your enemies before you go to war with them. :)

Best civ game so far.  Pros: The a.i is very good for a just release civ game. Diplomacy feels great. Loads of variety. Complex city planning.  Cons: The fog of war can get really long to get used to. Minor bugs. Steep learning curve for newcomers.

More options and variety when it comes to the civilization aspect of the game, which is a nice change of pace. Space on the map matters a lot more than civ 5 since improvements add housing and district locations are important and stop the yields of its space. City planning is much more of the game instead of just clicking the buildings you want.  The AI still is wonky, but that seems to never change. It definitely performs better than civ 5, but its interactions are glitchy. For example, when our borders connected, I kept getting penalties for having troops near the AI's borders even though those troops were in my borders. I have only played on Prince so maybe it gets better. Fingers crossed.  The new declare war mechanics are very nice. No flat war monger rates any more and an actual reason not to blitz your opponent.  The new government/civics system feels like a definite improvement. This is more of a time will tell thing, but being able to slot bonuses in to the different governments feels satisfying. Having culture unlock its own tech tree is also a nice change.  City state management seems a lot better. No more stacking cash to insta-buy all the city states (though maybe there is something like that, haven't played with late game techs/civics much). Sending in envoys represents a better long term investment for controlling city states and the quests are way less random and much more doable to get bonus envoys.  Trade routes making roads is also just great. Roads develop much more naturally now and mid tech units still let you put them down in specific places if you want. Trade has been buffed significantly overall, without being stupid like it was in BE, adding to the level of depth that the player can interact with outside of war.  The amenities system seems a little too streamlined, but that could be me not entirely understanding in. In my last game I expanded pretty heavily and it wasn't a problem until a long war and losing a city state's support caused a city to rebel. The rebel units were significant, so there is that, but if I had been paying more attention to just not expanding everywhere, it probably never would have happened.  Overall, I am going to say worth it, even at full price. My wife and I play together and we are both enjoying the expanded mechanics and I am glad they seem to have kept what worked from civ 5. I was hoping for limited unit stacking, mostly to help the AI do better in war, so hopefully that will be a thing. I don't want to go back to the doom stacks of civ 4, but letting the AI stack an archer on a warrior would help them navigate the hexes a lot easier.

THINGS I LIKE BETTER THAN I THOUGHT I WOULD: The cartoony look grows on you -- it's just different than Civ 5. Builders' limited usage -- instant improvements are a good trade-off. INTERESTING: The foxy, feisty Boudicca is now one of my generals instead of being a pain-in-the-♥♥♥ Civ 5 leader. Sumerian civilization instead of Assyrian -- I guess it doesn't matter since Gilgamesh reminds me of Ashurbanipal. Barbarossa instead of Bismarck as leader of Germany -- Bismarck was never a prick like Barbarossa seems to be. Diplomacy. Sending Envoys to City-States instead of gold to earn influence.  WTF?! After grinding this game for approx 50 hours I now feel confident to review it. So here goes.   Civ 6 is the first civilization game I ever played. For a life long turn based strategy game fan, that might be a bit weird. However, I'm sure there exists a multitude of amazing games I'll probably never even hear about so no big deal.   The game itself is a turn based long term strategy game where you guide your empire through the ages to achieve world dominance. The basic gameplay is simple enough for a newcomer like me to understand, but there is still depth if you want to optimize your strategies. There are almost an unlimited amount of strategies to pursue and even victory can be achieved by many different ways. Each approach has their pros and cons, and more often than not having a balance of economy, science, culture, religion and military seems like the way to go.  I don't want to bother my readers any longer and therefore I'll jump straight to the conclusions. Overall I'd rank this as one of the better turn based strategy games I've played, but not my favorite. (advance wars -series and chess will always be close to my heart). Still, it's a very entertaining and chill game to play with friends. I recommend to everyone who likes to think ahead and see how long term strategies pay out even if misfortunes would occur every now and then!  Best regards, yours truly, the man himself, me

Okay, after 100 hours of gameplay, I feel qualified to write this. This game gets a lot right and a few things wrong. I have won games through the space race and the cultural victory and have not lost on king level.  The good:  1. The graphics are excellent. People complain about the cartoony feel of them. I agree in some aspects. Units and leaders are cartoony. Terrain, wonders and features are not. The units could be less cartoony, but the leaders are EXCELLENT.  2. The depth of the game is much more advanced than other civ games. There are more kinds and types of resources that all help your cities develop. In Civ V, you needed food and luxuries to grow your cities. In 6, you need housing, food, and amenities which are kinda like luxuries but come from many sources. This is just one example.  3. The game is more shaped by the map than in previous editions. Climate and terrain are some of the most influential contributing factors to cultural development, and so terrain helps suggest and shape a path for your civilization.  4. The cultures are much more thought out with their advantages and disadvantages. Some cultures have a natural inclination towards a certain type of victory, but you can often pursue different avenues to victory.  5. City layout is both more pleasing to the eye and more fun to watch than in previous versions. Wonders are built over time and you can visibly check their progress as they are built.  6. Barbarians are a big challenge. They can really ruin your day. Single units against barbarians are just meat.  7. There are many paths to victory especially in the early game. There is no race to build certain wonders before the AI that greatly increase your chances of winning. In Civ 5, I would always race towards the great library and Chichen Itza. Now you have more things you can do.  Now the things that need improvement:  1. Diplomacy: The various leaders all have their own agendas and seem to follow them a bit illogically. You really need to watch your army strength in this version as even friendly nations will come after you if you have things they want. They are much less likely to come after you if you have a middling or higher ranked army. Several players have mentioned that historically friendly cultures will attack you without cause, and they are right.  2. The map is smaller, feels cramped and resources tend to clump up. In the game I'm working on now for example, there are no less than 7 pearls resources within 3 tiles of each other. Map generation is such that land masses almost universally stretch from north to south so that navies are pretty pointless in most games. Even in games set to islands.  3. Game pace feels wrong. Its soooo easy to race ahead in tech and culture that you do not have time to build most of the things you want till later eras. Many wonders are left behind till later eras. ie. I built the pyramids in the modern era... Everything seems to take too long to build especially ships and wonders. Often you can develop a tech, and start building that new unit and develop a newer, higher tech unit before you can build the first one....ie. ironclads -> battleship.  4. Wonders are interesting yet somewhat underwhelming in effect. Some are very nice like the ones that add civic cards to any government you are using at the time. Some are seriously meh. like the one that increase production for lake tiles... midly pointless in 90% of games.  5. If you survive past the medieval era, its very easy to get a tech lead and win any way you choose. I don't feel the need to specialize most of my cities to achieve the victory I want. The AI doesn't upgrade its units or build many more advanced ones. In my current game by example, Germany just threatened me with his huge army of horsemen against my army of musketmen and field cannon....Army strength calculation is warped so the AI always thinks its stronger than it is. The AI is stupid on attack often running from the city or unit it is just about to conquer because its units are weak and I just moved a supporting unit within attack range.  6. There are fewer types of maps to generate. You are limited to continents, pangea, islands, and one I just call random type. Even in islands mode, you can get huge land masses.  7. Ill use this point for a catchall for minor things. The UI doesn't have interfaces that allow you to keep track of many items ie. trade, population, land area, etc. Movement takes waaaaay too long to get anywhere. Exploration ai for your units is very very stupid... you often have to unstick your units to keep them moving in the right direction. etc  All in all this game has started out much better than Civ 5 did. There are doubtless expantions and patches coming to balance many of the issues I discussed. The game is VERY fun for the first 3rd of the game with the AI being both relevant and dangerous. The later game always ends with you dominating the AI because it forgets where its going.
Buy it when you're ready to spend countless of nights for something sweet!

A good change up from Civ 5.  It no longer takes 12 real time years to take over someone's city, and domination is much more balanced now. More like Civ 4 in that sense. Cities require walls to defend now which is logical and much more strategic. Cities without walls can be taken over very easily.  Culture is 100x better now. No longer is it just a simple mechanic with bonus trees, but now there is a culture 'tech' tree that you must put thought into when selecting policies, and governments (which make a return here in Civ 6).  Governments are strategic and an awesome idea. I just wish there were more of them. Which I'm sure will come in time (and with paid DLC)...  Barbarians are so much better now, they actually make sense, and add depth and not annoyance (for the most part) to the game. They spam units at times, but it only makes them more challenging when their fort is close to your base.  Diplomacy and diplomatic victories don't make a comeback in this series of Civ. Sad because I actually liked trying to hold leader of the global congress and trying to elect myself world ruler (which I never mananged to do sadly).  Computer AI is handicapped in this Civ game, which sucks for single player, and when players leave in multiplayer. But to counter that just play against real people. The game is more enjoyable that way anyhow, and you can roleplay better and more readily in multiplayer. Maybe robot drones, teleporters, advanced buildings, mechs, something to make it reasonable to tech incredibly fast to dominate with unstoppable technology. -0 - The graphics style was realism and not cartoonified... This was probably my least favorite change, but is something I can live with. Initial thoughts.  Most of the complaints about the A.I. seem to be from people who are playing the same way they played Civ 5 and are getting upset because this game responds differently to various strategies and playing styles.   The a.i. is different than it was in Civ 5. Thats a good thing; it keeps things interesting.  The other civs seem to adjust their agression based on a more sophisticated assesment of your intent rather than a simple calculation of the size and quality of your military.   When I setup a military geared civ I'm more likely to be attacked by other people. If I start putting military encampments in all of my cities, build a large standing army, and focus on developing military technology, my neighbors are more likely to attack me. They want to attack me before I get even bigger and stronger and can destroy them.  When I play a peaceful civ and build only a small military, without investing in encampments, and prioritize peaceful technology and policy, my neighbors tend to be much friendlier. Even when they are grumpy and denounce me they don't declare war if I'm not worth their time.  The new builders and road system is still a bit weird to me. I've always really enjoyed using legions of workers to build superior infrastructure from the early game. The new system makes that building more challenging. It's slower and I have to be more strategic about where I improve tiles. That seems super cool. I'm still getting used to it though.   The barbarians though....... They are a force to be reckoned with. It really changes the early game.

By all accounts, Civilization VI is a a clear upgrade to its predecessor even with both of Civ 5's expansions Gods & Kings and Brave New World. I was honestly worried that Civ 6 would feel incomplete and that I would ultimately have to wait for major expansions for the game to be adequate. However, Civ 6's gameplay has seen enough distinct changes that make this iteration in the franchise feel unique while still maintaining that Civilization feel. The district system is Civ 6's shining feature that actually makes city planning complex and interesting, compared to Civ 5 where once you got a feel for the game, city location felt like the only real strategy. Civ 6 is not without its fault, however, but many issues with the AI, warmongering penalties, etc have been addressed in the recent Fall Update patch. Civ 6 still needs some features that are clearly lacking, such as the city production queue and fixes/improvements to the UI (which in some ways feels like a downgrade to previous Civ games). But while Firaxis is often silent on their upcoming plans, they are clearly listening to the community, as seen in the recent patch, and I have high hopes for continuing improvements to the game and the future of its DLCs and expansions.

The game has been overhauled to the point where it is to be taken as a 'J.J Abrams Remake.' The engine, tech tree, building, everything has been re-done. This is not to say it is a bad game, but its unfamiliarity would even have new and old players ponder what everything does. Everything has been balanced very well, but noticing the turns take longer then expected.  Engine has been revamped. Remember ('Member'?') when map was huge and playing friends then disconnected? Ugh, that was abysmal. Well, They did NOT Fix THAT. So if you are planning on playing with friends, be prepared for a rude awakening.   Two trees you now have to research with that involves Science and Culture. This is familiar, but what they in fact did was put cards that you can change every 2-10 turns. One moment you are reinforcing your armies and pushing them out the door sort of speak. Then another you are conservative and cutting costs to not only maintain, but to save money and upgrade your units.  Units have been changed such as promotion and even the workers themselves. The workers have between 3-5 turns before they retire involuntary. This means you have to be careful on what you build, if its truly important or not. Traders build the roads and provide the eyes and ears of your competitors. Promotions have been greatly changed for the better. Not only do they add perks, but they also heal. Again, this is not to say these are bad, but different. Spies are used differently now too, used to be just a tab in the menu to determine where you want them to go. Now, they are actual units. You can have them steal money, technology, science whatever you like. Or can have them protect your own. Even the faith-based units have been changed a bit. There are apostle which can be used as warriors to defeat incoming faith which I admit is exceptional. There have been many times I was getting frustrated that there was nothing I could do before in Civilization V.  A.I. Is just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. If you have 6 people, 4 of them will hate you and will go to war with you for no reason.  Overall, it is highly satisfactory. If they fix the ever so minor issues I consider this a masterpiece in comparison with the previous games. I have completed over 470 hrs in civilization 5 and aiming to double with this game. Wait until this game get's fixed, because you are likely to still play with civilization V.

First of all: Don't listen to people with less than a hundred hours of gameplay - they haven't played the game enough yet to give a valid argument one way or the other. WILL UPDATE CONTINOUSLY.

Point by point logic train on the Civ community reviews:  - Most of the negative reviews on Steam currently (11/28/16) seem to be legit gripes. - There is a lot of talk about how Civ V is currently a better game.  - When Civ V came out, I recall there being a lot of complaints, AI motivations and actions being one of them.  - Civ V was updated and massaged over the years, and it became the great product it is today.  - I believe Civ VI is more fun than Civ V was at launch, and could eventually (through continued updates) be a better game than Civ V ever was.  - But again, most of the complaints folks currently have are legit...but for me personally they dont overshadow the tremedous fun I have playing this game with my friends.  - The series is moving in a good direction to stay fresh and bring in new Civ players...but they still have some work to do. And as long as they keep up regular support, updates, and additions, I think everything will be fine.  - That said, if you are upset by paying full price for a game while the devs work out fixing certain AI, UI, and balance issues...I would wait a bit to buy.

Played 40 Hours already.  I am having so much fun but even a dimwit as me sees the AI problem and occasional glitches. Lets round them up should we.  Pros:  *District Management, a swell feature and alot of fun puzzling them with each other. Each district can be constructed on a specific tile, that goes for world Wonders as well. Not all buildings crammed up into the city.  * Visual, many have complained that the cartoonish style looked like a mobile game. Its too childish, yada,yada boom de yada. FOr me, i have no problem. I played Borderlands which had a cartoonish graphical style, i played Rollercoaster Tycoon 3 which falled in to the same opinion, oh its cartoonish.. For me, its just makes things clearer.  * City State Diplomacy, finally no more 'here ya go with this gold now you are my B****!'. They removed the gold gifting from Civ V which made it stale and boring, here we go with Envoys. A specific type of resource that can be used to gain influence and become suzerian. An oh Suzerian, a new type of improvement that grants each citystate a diffrent type of unique bonues, some are awesome and some are medicore (Preslav.... I still love you but give me something else instead of combat bonus towards cavalary on hills).   Cons:  * AI, here comes the biggest concern for me. Playing against a stupid AI makes me feel smart and i dont like it.... Honestly when i pull off something that makes players goes 'OH My'... Myself be like: 'Is this too easy?' I always sucked at video games from the beginning at 5 years old. But thats just me but something is off... Really off, i had a hard time achieving a victory in Civ V on King but here i am rolling through both science, culture and somewhat domination on score/lead (i am not a warmongerer).... Something is definitley off, at least i should be winning in science.  *Glitchy, a glitch in the system? I have not encountered hard ones that made me start a new game and delete my previous save but i have encountered some nice mostly visual glitches. For example, the low texture on leaders hair switches off and on when i start my Civ 6 from steam. Its something todo that i did not get all the info from the start so i have to change graphics in option which then leads me to restart whole Civ 6 because Graphic Change. Also some embarked units acts like Jesus and walks on water until it registers that they are on a boat.. Just visual ones.  * Sorting, here is something that makes me cringe. Sorting.... Sorting my traderoutes, sorting the civ that leads culture... Demographics, where is that? Sorting Citystate (may not be that nessecary)  Here is my final value, its a solid 8/10. Civ V delivered it a bit better as a 8.01/10 but this one came close. =)  Final Score: 8/10, recommends it.

[Latest Review]  Now after few patches I'm ready to change this review to recommended. There are still issues that needs to be fixed but at least the game is now somewhat enjoyable to play.  [Original Review]  As much as I'd like to give a recommendation I can't while the game is being what it is at the moment.   For me the biggest flaw is the awfull UI. It's buggy (misleading information here and there), not responsive (mouse hover is a pain), not enough information (it simply just hides information that should be there), not fast to use (not enough hotkeys etc.) and a lot of other little things. It doesn't courage you to plan carefully which makes this game very shallow.  There are also bunch of bugs that makes me wonder if the game is working properly in other areas. Trading is broken, I've faced some crashing in certain situations where I'm changin policies (crashes to the desktop) and minor bugs here and there. How can I trust that this is what they wanted in a first place.  I know Civ 4 and 5 were not perfect at their launch either but that shouldn't be a reason to give this game a positive feedback at the moment. Almost every thing that bothers me about this game is kind of a bug that should have been caugh in in-house testing progress. If they intentionally released the game knowing these problems exists then I think they deserve a negative feedback.  Yes, they made some very interesting changes to the game and added some nice new mechanisms but those can't outcome the fact that this game feels like a pre-release version.  Reviews you can see at the store page written by some companies such as PC Gamer, IGN and Game Informer: 'I'll never need another Civ game in my life besides this one', 'Possibly the biggest and deepest game in the series' 25-year history' and 'One of the most rewarding 4X experiences to date'. Did they even play the game? Those are some bs reviews.
